150496102.review:
There are good remakes of classic games, and bad remakes of classic games.

This definitely falls into the former category.

For fans of the original game (like myself; I grew up playing the first two Spyro games on PS1) there's a lot to like here. The new graphics are gorgeous, but the developers retrained the original level and character design for the most part. The music is solid, and the voice work is excellent and even features some VAs from the original games. If you don't like the new music, there is an option to use the older music (a nice bonus for us older fans).

New players will have fun with this title too. The gameplay is pretty simplistic - kill enemies, find gems/eggs/dragons, fight a boss occasionally. But the level design is quite intelligent even though the levels are now over 20 years old, and the characters are fun. There's a lot of replayability if you're the type to go for 100% completion, but you'll get hours of playtime even if you're just playing through the game in a hurry (remember, this is actually three full-length games). The controls are straightforward and intuitive, but I wouldn't try to play with a keyboard and mouse. Overall there's not a lot of depth, but if you're looking for a game you can pick up and play for 10 minutes or two hours this is a good choice.

I'm currently playing on the Steam Deck and this is a great travel title. I'm a bit surprised at the near 40GB size of the game, but that and some small stutters on the loading screens are my only complaints (I'm running the game from an SD card, so you'll probably get better performance if you run the game from the Deck's internal drive). Actual gameplay is buttery smooth on the Deck, and the battery draw is average (much less than something like Baldur's Gate 3, but more than something like Hollow Knight. The game also plays very nicely on my older gaming laptop, I get 60fps @ 1080p consistently. As this is a fast-paced game, consistent framerates are important - I haven't seen any dips below 60fps except on loading screens.

Overall I recommend this for new and old gamers alike. Super elite pro gamers might not find it challenging enough but for the rest of us it's a great way to kill an afternoon. Recommended if you've got younger players or want to take a trip down memory lane.

150052963.review:
I recommend this game but...only just. 
The first 3 Spyro games were a important part of my childhood, I loved them to death and still do.
For the most part the Reignited Trilogy does a great job at recreating the feel and aesthetic of the originals in spectacular detail, any complaints I have about how the game looks are nitpicks and are not impact-full enough to tarnish it.
My main complaints are in regards to how the game plays.
Before release, throughout the Trilogy's development it was claimed several times that they aim to have these remakes play exactly as the originals, with a few modern injections of course, such as a stick controlled camera. 
I consider this effort to be unsuccessful due to the following changes.

1.Both flight and swimming mechanics in the remake have directional momentum implemented to them, this was not the case in the original games. The additional physics cause Spyro to drift in air and water, making precision movements and collecting underwater gems etc more difficult than it should be. 

2. Incremental Super Charge. This was a mechanic present in the original Spyro 1 when using a Super Charge ramp. Spyro would gain more and more speed the longer he supercharged down an incline. This feature was added, unnecessarily to both Spyro 2 and 3 speedway levels. This coupled with the aforementioned flight drift, considerably changes how you must approach these levels, which were faithfully recreated and not designed around having these additional physics. In Spyro 2 and 3 Supercharge should not be an incrementing variable but a constant. This isn't even an issue of having to create extra code, as the code for Supercharge with a constant speed is already in the game, as can be seen when using the Supercharge "Gate" power ups in Spyro 2. 

3. The most egregious change made to the games, affects every main level in all 3 games. 
Sparx the Dragonfly will not collect gems if Spyro is not touching the ground. This forces the player to back track and do several passes through areas to collect gems that in the original would be collected on the initial pass. This is most noticeable in sections that use super fly power up, such as Gnasty's Loot in Spyro 1 and the cave at the beginning of Sunrise Spring in Spyro 3. But of course extends to every gem in the game that should be collected by jumping near or gliding past. 
Whether this missing feature was a developer oversight or deliberate, it slows down and interrupts the flow of game-play to an irritating degree, an issue that, several years on, has still not been solved by either developer or the modding community.

149567704.review:
As a fan of the original, and this point having played more than 75% of the trilogy, I think I can approach this review impartially without nostalgia glasses as there's a lot I do like and I lot I don't like about this remake.

Positives:
Great remastered soundtrack, stunning visuals (excluding frame rate issues marring them), well designed character models, and good voice actors. The small amount of unique additional content is also pretty cool. I enjoy looking at this game, and listening to the soundtrack.

Negatives:
I'm not a big fan of the controls, which is the primary reason why I don't recommend this game. A mixture of janky camera work (even more so than the originals), motion blur (which at least can be switched off), and Spyro feeling more like a cat than a dragon, leads to an underwhelming and sometimes nauseating experience. I can only stomach (literally) playing this game for about an hour at most at a time, as my stomach churns from the sudden rotations and zooming of the camera. I only get this kind of motion sickness when I feel out of control of something (e.g. the back-seat of a car). I don't experience this kind of feeling with original trilogy, so it is definitely worth having someone with motion sickness playtest future titles (if any get made). The only other gripe I had was also control-related, and that's the vehicles, especially the skateboard. As this is a platformer, the controls can make or break this game, and sadly, even though I intend to gradually finish the game (when my stomach allows it), I will probably never play this game again after that. 

I hope they take what they did well from this game, and fix the controls if there ever is a future title, as it is a real shame that I have to mark a game with a lot of love in it as a thumbs-down. Of course if you don't get any kind of motion-sickness, it could still be worth a play for you. 

Edit: after finishing 100% of all three game, I can say that Spyro 3 is a broken mess in many areas, especially the skateboarding and massive frame drops I was experiencing at random times that made the game unplayable without rebooting, or switching around graphics settings every 10-20 minutes. This was enough of a blowout that I've lowered by original score of 4/10 to 3/10. Just play the originals at this point.

Rating: 3/10 (really below average)
Any%: ~7 hours (across the trilogy)
100%: ~20-30 hours (30 for me as I can't stomach moving too quickly)
Value: ~$20 seems like a fair price for someone who doesn't have the problems that I have, but with the frame drops and nausea, just play the originals.

149162246.review: Very different, very coo... er, hot.  Truly astonishing blend of Pilotwings with a deep inspiration from Yoshi's Island and Shiny's Earthworm Jim this game remaster is NOT TO BE MISSED.  It is so near perfect in execution it forms a sort of cultural touchstone moment of sights, sounds, nostalgia and dragon magic.  Spyro's edgy yet loving personality is the cure to the modern woes of misguided companies and failing franchises.  Each level brims over with a deep source of life and animated adventure.  Most noticeable is the rare atmosphere of Spyro which is similar to Jim... it has the humor yes, however there is artistic mastery at work here which supercharges this collection into another higher realm of existence.  Even the music finds a balance between fun, silly rhythms and awe inspiring ambient textures worthy of Brian Eno or Harold Budd.  If you like fun, animation, dreams, dragons, Dragoons or maybe just flying then this is very recommended.  Only flaws are perhaps the conflicting controls and some ambiguous ledges.  Disney, Pixar, WB, Dreamworks take note and be in awe of the phenomenon that is ... Spyro Reignited Trilogy.  Special thanks to Miharu for making the sale!

149009049.review:
The Spyro Reignited Trilogy is a fantastic remake of the classic Spyro games from the PlayStation era. Toys for Bob really gets what makes Spyro special, though a bit more technical fine-tuning would've been great.

There are some tiny glitches that can briefly take you out of the game, but, all in all, it's a fun experience. I ran into a strange bug in Spyro 2 where Spyro forgot how to swim after I loaded the game, and I had to restart my progress to move forward (thankfully, my 120% save in Spyro 1 was fine).

To fix the issue, I disabled 'cloud saves' in the Game Properties settings, and I started making manual backup saves, just in case.

Another hiccup was in Spyro 1, where a door wouldn't open because my frame rate was too high. Switching to 30fps fixed that problem.

In summary, despite these minor bugs, Spyro Reignited Trilogy has quickly become one of my all-time favorite games. You should definitely consider adding it to your collection.

148365877.review:
10/10 Overall
Due to it having three games ill give each one a review
Some very minor spoilers in this review, if you played the original game or have seen the game's movie/cutseens or have played this on ps4/ps5 then theirs no worries.

********* For all three games *********
*Music
Great & dynamic for standing still, running, & moving in every level & hub world & is just a banger of a soundtrack.

*Gameplay & Controls
smooth & responsive with the camera control being added it helps a lot in areas & makes things easier then it was in the original game, if you press the (L3) then sparks will point to the closest gem helping you collect & find things alot faster & safer, due to the remaster side of the game & better camera the mini games are alot easier to handle, playing this game on controller is not only easier but helps in some areas & mini games it's ok on keyboard but if you have an Xbox or PlayStation controller use it as it feel way better, there are times were some AI are smarter or dumber then their original PS1 counterparts witch either makes it easier or a small challenge.

*Graphics
Very nice & beautiful even on low settings, the game looks & feels amazing even on the lowest graphical settings witch is nice to have for highend & lowend computers, its stunning on highest but dose not lose much on lowest settings.

********* Spyro the Dragon (Game 1) *********
*Story
nothing was change from its original plot more was added making it more realistic & better moments & animations.

*Original vs Reignited
In the Original game the dragons were bare bones & just a few different dragons models with color swaps & sometimes reused the same voices and for the most part said "thank you for releasing me" was about 95% of what dragons said, in the Reignited the dragons all have different body types & shapes more detailed colors & different outfits & animations as well as the whole "thank you for releasing me" is now 5% of what dragons say while 95% of them say something not said before, only other change is in gnasy cove the enemies held guns & fired bullets in the original while in Reignited they have goo/slime guns and shoot blobs at you witch i don't really care about.

*Bosses, Enemies, & Difficulty
Not much can be said about this, the bosses & enemies as well as the games difficulty is pretty much very easy unless your very new to games or platforms, the bosses do seem to have a little more delay/slowed attack speed & a little bigger hitboxs then the original game had witch is not a bad thing its very hard to die in this game unless your really bad at judging the distance of your flame attack & charge speed just remember "big guys flame, small guys ram, big metal guys push off cliff"

*Achievement's, Challenges & Playtime
The challenges and achievements are pretty easy to get you will get most of them just by playing you will get like 75+% of them if your getting 100% in each level, the total playtime it takes to complete all Challenges & Achievement's and 120% the first game it will take you about 6~7 hours or more if your bad so its not hard to do.

**Bugs & Issues

there was not any bugs or issues to note other then Gulps AI being alot more aggressive then the original to the point i think its a coding bug.

148316982.review:
A couple of my friends told me that they loved this game and one of them ended up buying it for me, but unlike them, I never played any of the Spyro games when I was younger. While I don't think I enjoyed the game as much as they did, I still had a fun time playing through it, and I think it's a good game if you're looking for an easy, relaxing collectathon.

The first game in the trilogy is definitely the weakest. The game looks great and controls well for the most part (aside from the camera being awful sometimes, which turned out to be a common theme for the entire series), but most of the game is very easy and simple and the story was pretty simplistic as well. I also encountered a few unfortunate bugs, including one where the Alpine Ridge level became impossible to complete unless the framerate was lowered, as well as some physics bugs where I randomly lost speed or got stuck inside things.

The second game improved on the first quite a bit. The story is more complex and interesting than the story from the first game, and the cutscenes before entering each area were also pretty neat. It also added a bunch of neat new abilities and a variety of extra challenges to complete, which were pretty fun as well. I also appreciated the ability to point to treasure that was missed on each level, that you didn't have to collect something from every enemy in every level, the more interesting and challenging boss fights, and the cool and useful reward for fully completing the game. There were still a few bugs though, such as gems suddenly becoming impossible to collect, enemies getting stuck inside terrain, or challenge progress tracking incorrectly.

The third game made a number of changes from the second game much like the second game did, but I didn't personally like all these changes as much. The story is still good, but I didn't love it quite as much as the second game. The world design was definitely better with bigger and more interesting worlds, and I loved that each level had it's own set of different creatures, although I missed the starting/ending cutscenes for each level that the second game had. I enjoyed the music in this game the most out of the three, but I also found this game to have the most tedious and frustrating challenges in the series. This game also added some other characters that you get to play as briefly, but most of the time I just felt like they were more clunky and they mostly just made me miss playing as Spyro. This game was also by far the buggiest of the three. An NPC getting stuck on one level forced me to restart it multiple times, and I encountered numerous other issues such as getting stuck in terrain constantly, certain basic abilities suddenly failing to work (like jumping or gliding), and Spark sometimes pointing in a random direction when searching for remaining treasure.

[b]TL;DR[/b] Although I found the games to be pretty easy and a bit buggy at times, and I didn't enjoy every challenge the game threw at me, the games have fantastic visuals, great music, good stories (in the second and third game at least), and are fairly fun overall. If you enjoyed the Spryo games when you were younger or are looking for an easy collectathon game to relax with, you'll enjoy this collection of games as well.

148290510.review:
Exceedingly ordinary.

Exploration is dull. Platforming is one-dimensional. Environments are visually innocuous. The music is mediocre at best.

The game consists of running around sterile fantasy settings collecting trash until you get bored enough to see what forgettable, brightly-colored gem depository is next in line for you to begrudgingly clean up. 

Making progress is usually easy, but after finishing levels, the game looks at you like an underachieving child whose overbearing parent thinks that ninety percent isn't a passing grade. Everything is measured in percentages. It'd be much easier to play along with the games' completionist expectations if there was any dietetic assistance or the slightest intrinsic itch to do so.

There's also a frustrating glitch where at higher framerate limits, which the game defaulted to, Spyro starts to slide and movement occasionally breaks.

Chances are if you don't have a programmed fondness for Spyro or aren't within the game's original age demographic, this collection won't do anything for you.

148214230.review:
Nunca habia jugado un Spyro y de momento lo que he jugado ha sido agradable
Le pasa como a los primeros Crash, son juegos bastante cortos

El primer juego me lo he terminado ya en cosa de 8 horas.
Es bastante arcade, ir de nivel en nivel, conseguir todo y siguiente
Hay personajes pero literalmente te dicen "hola" y se van, lo cual es ironico porque tienen diseños muy detallados pero no tienen nada de profundidad. No hay mucha historia mas alla de "este es el malo: a por él" y por algun motivo da igual el enemigo, que 4 ascuas de Spyro lo mandan con San Pedro.
Los controles son bastante simples, aunque algo difíciles de dominar. Lo único negativo del primer juego (es posible que lo vea en los demás juegos) es que los niveles de vuelo tienen los controles invetidos y no se pueden modificar (y yo lo siento pero los controles invertidos son un asco)

El segundo juego se me ha hecho incluso mas corto que el primero (de hecho creo que hay menos niveles o eso me ha parecido). Innova pero no mucho. Mete un par de habilidades nuevas, y de paso las gemas sirven para algo (el capitalismo se inventó en Spyro 2 xd). Por otro lado, es un poco menos arcade. Ahora hay mas diálogos, más personajes (unos cuantos furros) y los mundos tienen sus "mini historias" y en vez de "dragones" como coleccionable ahora hay orbes que se consiguen generalmente con misiones secundarias. Parte mala, que por meter las nuevas habilidades, te medio obliga a hacer backtracking en algun momento si quieres completar todos los niveles (aunque realmente a partir del segundo mundo ya puedes hacer casi todo bien). Las secundarias en parte alargan los niveles al contrario que los dragones que solo era acercarte y ya.

El tercer juego probablemente queda como el mejor de los 3 solo por el hecho de incluir más personajes jugable aparte de Spyro (lo cual es un soplo de aire fresco para el gameplay que lleva siendo el mismo durante 2 juegos). Comparado con el 2, hay algo mas de narrativa (aunque se han quitado las cinemáticas que habia al inicio y final de cada nivel del 2).

Juntando los 3 juegos, solo he encontrado un bug en el 3 donde un vehículo no se mueve por encima de los 60 fps. El ricachón (el oso con monóculo) es fácilmente el mejor personaje del juego. En plan, es un asqueroso pero hace gracia y acabas teniendole cariño (claro que si no vais completando los niveles a full entiendo que cuando le veais os va a dejar en la bancarrota, a mi siempre me sobraban las gemas a raudales)

Comentario general, es un buen pack  a un buen precio. No son juegos demasiado complicados (comparados por ejemplo con Crash xd) pero aún así son divertidos de jugar y de completar. Eso si, le sobra un poco de propaganda furra.

147540537.review:
[u][b]In Short[/b][/u]
These remasters were very well done! The games, on their own, were very enjoyable even though they slightly differed from one another. +1 perfect games!

[hr][/hr]
[u][b]Detailed Version[/b][/u]
This was my second playthrough of the trilogy and I remembered close to nothing about the game. I believe that allowed me to have an even better time. Now, I'll go through the individual games and give my two cents.

[i][u]Spyro the Dragon[/u][/i]
A way to get additional lives... After you defeated an enemy and collected their gem, anytime you defeated that enemy afterwards, they'd drop an orb (or soul). Once you collected 20, you'd get an additional life. It kinda gave you a reason to go to already completed levels, which was nice! One thing I didn't notice until revisiting the game was the lack of the hover ability while gliding. It threw me off before I realized it was simply missing.

[i][u]Spyro 2: Ripto's Rage![/u][/i]
Then there was the introduction of various learnable abilities. They added some not so very needed, but very much welcome variation to the mechanics, which I loved. What I didn't love was how you learned said abilities... I was never sure if I had to venture back or if it was learned somewhere down the line. I wish it were more clear where, or when, you'd learn such abilities.

[i][u]Spyro: Year of the Dragon[/u][/i]
We could play as other characters! This was really fun since it was kind of like playing a whole other game for a bit. The only one that was a bit irritating for me was Sparx. Not actually playing as Sparx, but how to unlock Sparx's worlds. I, for the life of me, could not figure out how to get Zoe to unlock the worlds. I ended up Googling it and finding out I had to beat the homeworld's boss, which sounds so backwards to me...
 
Throughout the trilogy, my ongoing gripes were with the camera movement (especially underwater), the lack of world tracking unless you've traveled to said world, and no further use of the rescued dragons once rescued. I won't fault such an old title for all that and it didn't affect my enjoyment very much, if at all.

[i][u]Please thumbs up. I'd greatly appreciate it![/u][/i]

146906977.review:
Antes que nada, puede que mucho de lo que voy a decir aquí se deba en realidad a mi computadora, la cual se encuentra en sus últimas instancias de vida, por lo que cuando tenga la oportunidad de volver a probar este juego en una PC más moderna y con más aguante y vea cambios a esta primera experiencia, actualizaría esta reseña.

Ahora sí. Este juego es un clásico de la infancia de muchos niños de los 90. Un trilogía de plataformas en un mismo juego lista para jugarse. La realidad es que es una excelente idea. Los gráficos son preciosos, se mejora el diseño de los personajes y la música icónica está ahí. También sus controles no han sido tocados como tal... y quizá ese es un pequeño problema. Hay un ligero cambio de dinámicas en Spyro 2 que continua en Spyro 3, y al ser un remake uno podría esperar que el primer juego tendría estas mejoras, pero no es el caso. No habló de la mejora de trepar paredes, nadar ni el salto con cabezazo, estoy hablando de una pequeña mejora el momento de planear. Y su ausencia puede volverse un dolor de cabeza en algunas ocasiones para quien esté juego los tres juegos al mismo tiempo.

Aunque bueno, este no es el punto por el cual el juego tiene el pulgar abajo. Sino algo frecuente es la bajada de frames que se llega a dar en varios niveles, en especial de Spyro 3, al mismo tiempo que había pantallas de carga muy duraderas que podían prolongarse hasta los 5 minutos, cosa que también se repetía cuando un aliado nos daba instrucciones. Esto hacía que varios niveles se generara una terrible sensación de mareo tras un par de minutos, así como frustración por perder una vida y esperar a que volviera a cargar el nivel.

Todos estas circunstancias hacían que jugar este juego se volviera cansado en algunas ocasiones.

Repito, esto es muy probable que se deba a los problemas de mi propia PC, algo que tendría que revisar por mi propia cuenta.

A pesar de esto, la trilogía de Spyro es un juego bastante bueno y divertido, que, sí bien jugar los tres de forma continua nos demuestra los repetitiva que llegó a ser la trilogía original, no pierde su encanta y carisma. Este juego, en mejores condiciones si lo recomendaría a jugadores que son fanáticos de los plataformeros/colectaton, a los más pequeños de la casa o a los fanáticos de esta franquicia y en especial de los juegos originales de Play Station.

146703784.review:
So - about a week and a half ago, I managed to catch COVID for the second time. It’s sucked, as expected… but at least my time off work has allowed me to finally dive into this collection. And honestly, laying in my bed with my Steam Deck, and constantly being hit with the feeling of “oh my god, I actually remember [i]every[/i] detail of this level” helped to make fighting this junk off again just a little easier.

It really was a treat to re-experience all the same solid action-platforming, fun characters, and the regular stream of goofy mini games of the originals - just with a new coat of paint, some honestly gorgeous cutscenes, and a load of entertaining new voice performances. Cloud saves, multiple save slots for the entire collection, and a [b]much[/b] expanded options suite are also present; and help to make these games not feel [i]completely[/i] ancient.

If anyone cares to know whether I think there’s any negatives? Well… Year of the Dragon is still kinda mid, like it’s always been. Ripto’s Rage somehow whips just as hard as it did on day one, though. Also, all of Unreal’s 4’s classic issues are present - weird issues with shader compilation, occasional stuttering, and annoying cutscene audio delay and crackling are all here. Other than that, though - I think this is a damn fine package. Ran quite smoothly on my Steam Deck, with minimal tweaking - so I have to imagine that most any mid-range rig built between ~2017 and now should have virtually no issues with it.

With all that in mind, I honestly can’t recommend this collection enough - and even though they definitely took some liberties in their reimagining of the trilogy, I still appreciate it for having it’s own cohesive style. Major props to Nicholas Kole’s work, for just being unbelievably gorgeous to look at. Seriously - if you’re like me, you’re gonna want to get [i]every[/i] skill point, just to admire his efforts a little more before you move on to something else.

As a final note - congrats to all the developers for the game having recently crossed its much-deserved ten million sales milestone! I hope Toys for Bob and Vicarious Visions are eventually let loose from the live service mines to remake (or just [b]make[/b]) more games like these.

146659900.review:
I grew up playing Spyro as a kid, so when this was first announced, I was overjoyed when this was first released. This game takes a lot of what Naughty Dog did back in the day and gave it a fresh coat of paint and then some.

The game play feels as good as when I played it when it first came out. The controls feel responsive, fluent, and fun to play. The locales are BEAUTIFUL, and seeing many iconic places like Autumn Plains, Artisans, and other worlds in HD made me wish this was the game I had as a kid.

There are sadly still some issues I experienced, such as some strange hitboxes when gliding, and a strange bug that made Spyro move when the framerate was set over 120 FPS. But they didn't harm my experience as much as I thought they would. A big bonus for me was being able to enjoy the Classic and Reignited soundtracks whenever I wanted to, allowing me to feel the nostalgia again.

If you haven't played the original, this is worth finishing to the end. Completing it isn't too much harder if you want to go for 100% and beyond. I'd give this game a 9/10

146503732.review:
Excellent remakes of great games.

The Spyro trilogy is far from perfect, but I respect the decision to keep the remakes faithful and stick to a graphics overhaul and some simple quality of life improvements like a modern save system. Nothing that Toys for Bob was in charge of could have been done much better. The game looks great and sounds better than ever, but each level is still instantly recognizable even 20 years later.

I only have one real complaint, and it's that tying game physics to frame rate is simply unacceptable in the 21st century. Especially when the game is literally impossible to complete on a higher than 30 framerate. Yes, it's only one level where it's a real issue, and you only have to lock the frame rate for 10 seconds or so, but that should have never passed quality inspection. Not for a major release with a big money publisher behind it. Doubly not when higher frame rates are an option offered in the in-game menus.

The loading times are also weirdly long for a relatively simple game. The problem shouldn't be my computer, because games with significantly larger levels and more complex graphics load much faster. Both of these technical issues probably stem from the PC port being outsourced. Loading screens aren't frequent enough to make it a major hindrance, but it sticks out.

146454242.review:
When the remake was announced, I was having a fit of happiness and excitement. 

After playing through the game like three times, I've noticed how much biased I was towards it thanks to the hype.

Nostalgia may invoke senses that have us enjoy the original games only, but it can also show us if the remake is good or not.

Spyro Reignited has more issues than improvements over the originals. Sure the graphics are all shiny and all dragons from original games have their own unique design and the cutscenes became more lively... that's it.

The first game in the remake was done pretty well, I enjoyed all the unique designs, the levels looked really pretty, the added skill points were a nice touch and it controlled okay. I am not a biggest fan of most of the dragon designs but I will give them A+ for effort. Also the swimming, charging and flying controls are... not great.

Enter the second and we have:
Unnecessary censorship
Broken collisions
Crappy redesigns of your favourite characters
Butchered details like the orb bouncing and delivery lines and Juliette voice
Most voice acting losing it's charm


And the third game, which can be downright unplayable and is everything I mentioned above but worse.

Do I recommend it?
Yes and no, I do think it is worth playing at least once or twice.

Excuse me while I go play the originals.

I have experienced crashes and the game minimizing itself for no reason, just know that this PC port is not the worst I have seen but it is not the best. The original Spyro Trilogy was a huge part of my childhood, as said I played the remaster on my PS4 when it released. I love the game so much. The Reignited Trilogy made me feel like I was a kid again and I couldn't stop playing it. The graphics are cutesy and clean which makes the game look like something I saw in the old games back when I was a kid, it's beautiful and some of the worlds look so cozy I could stay there forever, I once never felt like looking at something and being "no this is not like it was before".
Some "upgrades" in different worlds (ahem... the huge talk about the guns being removed from the gnorcs) don't really bother me at all, but also it's a laugh that some people say they we're removed so the game would be more "kid-friendly", I feel like that doesn't change the experience at  all.

If you have played the original trilogy or you just like exploration, collecting ect ect. this game is for you. I can also say this game fits also for the youngest of players as their first video game (like it was mine back in 2001).

145836386.review:
I've played challenging games in the past, and I've beaten many, but the original game is just so horribly designed.  Jumping requires timing that is way too precise for a game that is catered towards kids.  The "hidden challenges" mainly those requiring use of the ramps are almost impossible to figure out without a guide.  Trying to 100% every map is where the challenge is, but the bosses are braindead easy to beat.

Ripto's Rage greatly improves upon the original, with challenges that are fair, and MAKE SENSE.  They aren't stupid or impossible to figure out for the most part.  While the sequel is hands down the superior game, it does manage to slip in some BS that was present from the original game in the form of hidden items that would've taken a guide to find.

The third game in the series is easily the best.  It's a much more relaxing experience, and for the most part, it is a relatively easy game, with a decent experience. 

Overall, if you're going to play this series, it gets better.  The first game is the hardest, and if you can manage to get through that, then it'll coast and get easier as you go along.  Some of the challenges in all of the games are pretty bad due to collision issues, or other glitches.  The frame rate is also a rather big issue in my opinion.

145781998.review:
This game has a consistent problem with its save system that makes playing it on the Steam Deck not recommended.
If you go offline, which the deck does a lot, it'll start saving to the wrong folder and overwrite your save with an older one the next time you load up.

The only solutions for this are for desktops and require backing up your save every time before you exit the game. This isn't possible on Deck as desktop mode will close the game and is the only way to find the appropriate folder and back up.

This game receives no more patches so this will not be fixed.

145041880.review:
[h1]I am Fire. I am... DEATH[/h1]
[b]Cruelty's off the charts[/b]
Meet Spyro - a purple fire-breathing wyrm. 
Under [u]your[/u] command this beast terrorizes castles, parks, burns poor animals, villagers and buildings. Nobody is safe (from you) - nor giant Karens, nor friendly frogs, not even terrified chickens! Chasing, ramming, igniting everyone to death is gameplay core. Dewit!
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3017149903
[b]NSFK[/b]
That's right - Spyro is not safe for kids. As if murdering those folks wasn't enough, Spyro adds adult content.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3021563846
Fairies fly in mini-skirts and lustily kiss the dragon here and there. You get a chance to roast them later (literally). There's more! Horny pixies locked in cages. Trolls flash green butt cracks and slap them cheeks. Pervy draenei flirt with innocent dragon... the list goes on!

[b]Wholesome Trilogy[/b]
There's three games, where the next one gets better and more complex.
1st adventure: simply run, jump, glide, collect gems, hit enemies... drown and fall to death (jump controls response suck!) in between and repeat so 30+ times.

2nd crusade: all of the above, plus you can swim now! It's like playing GTA SA after VC: "whoa, I CAN swim!". A lot of quests are water based, so embrace your aqua nature.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3021948635
Sequel feels larger, yet repetitive due to its secondary objectives which are made of compulsory backtracking: new abilities are locked, yet NPCs ask for gathering animals, chests, accessing areas which are out of reach for now. 
Moreover: we have mini games too! Riding carts, flying through various rings, playing hockey, pursuing hopping thieves and many others.

3rd quest: all of the above AND you get to play as new animals: Penguin, Kangaroo, Yeti & Monkey. Each has unique powers and either helps during boss episodes. Heavy accent is made on skating, you better train the dragon doing flips and spins.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
Spyro Trilogy is casual, colourful & cute. And simply super! There's plenty content and missions to keep you amused and busy. Is this enough?

144949589.review:
Spyro Reignited Trilogy contains, as the name implies, all three Spyro games.
From the moment you start the remaster, you lose track of time. Especially if you have played the game in the past, you are completely in the game again and the polished graphics also help with this.

Year of the dragon on the steam deck: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PHWCPJqwgTk

Remember how every time you mistimed a jump, you had a heart attack that nearly sent you crashing into an abyss? Or how you wanted to swing your controller, including PlayStation, because cable, through the living room with your sweaty palms, when you just couldn't beat a final boss?
It's all now replayable in brightly colored HD. The sweet memories of your innocent childhood shoot back into the synapses of your brain in one thrilling burst. As if yesterday you were allowed to press Spyro's buttons for the first time.

The Gateway To Glimmer on a steam deck: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9WHwiTCplu4

Even the loading screens look wonderful and they should be. You'll encounter them many times and while that's fun at first because of the mini-game that gives you the option to spit fire or flap Spyro's wings, it quickly gets tedious.
They last a lot longer than you'd expect and keep popping up when you move from one area to another or when you die.

Spyro the dragon on a steam deck: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qho77BhOVCE

The Spyro Reignited Trilogy is an example of a very nice remaster. You can tell that love and attention has gone into the designs. The revised soundtrack is also strong.
I think people who played the original games in the distant past are going to have a blast with the bundle.
The strong nostalgic feelings are just as present in the crash bandicoot trilogy.

144133853.review:
This is my first time playing a Spyro game of any kind as I was a Nintendo 64 kid. Overall I'm fairly happy with the entire experience as I love platformers and the fantasy theme is a lot of fun. All characters, enemies, and levels have unique assets which shows a lot of time was put into the artistic design. The games do have a weird physics tied to frame rate issue, most likely an unfortunate symptom of the port. The game must remain at about 30 frames or platforms, walls and a couple boss fights do not work at all. Its weird but 30 frames is plenty to enjoy the game so I'd advise to switch it as soon as you start playing to avoid frustration. The trilogy as a whole is a mixed bag gameplay wise so I'm going to go through them one at a time. I did make an effort to make myself at least familiar with key parts of the original set of games to make a solid opinion.

Spyro the Dragon with all the achievements as well as getting 120% took me about 8 hours. I personally loved this one, the amount of care that was put into this one was great. All the levels are standard, there aren't any crazy platforming tricks you have to pull off that aren't the standard jumping or gliding making everything as smooth as possible. One thing in this game that I can't believe they took the time to do is with the elder dragons which all have completely different designs as in the original they were all the same shape with varied colors only. It definitely reads as the first game in the series as it is a little more simple than the other two in the set but that isn't a bad thing as sometimes bare bones is better than overly complicated mechanics. A complaint which is obviously just attempting to keep consistent with the original is the boss fights in this. They are simple platforming challenge, chase, catch up and hitting them. The last boss is the same way which is sort of disappointing but this is my only complaint. Other than that great title in the series and a great starting point.

Spyro: Ripto's Rage took me about 15 hours to 100% and get all but one achievement. I really liked this one too and found playing it to be relaxing and pretty standard as it was with the first. I never had to do any heavy back tracking and was impressed with the increase in content but not in an overwhelming or unwelcome way. Ripto is a better villain than Gnorc not from a design stand point but that he seems more relevant and he has more of a presence in the story at least it felt like it. I wish the collectible in the game was more interesting but that is minimal. Every level had a start and ending cut scene which was kind of cute. The boss fights in this one are a very welcome change from the first and play like standard boss fights rather than the platforming ones. They are adorable and the final fight against Ripto is also pretty neato. Like the first a lot of care was put into this one and I was really happy the entire time I played it.

Spyro: Year of the Dragon is where I started to have a few issues. It took me about 15 hours to 117% finish the game and get most but not all the achievements. I really wanted to just finish this one after awhile because this ended up being my least favorite of the three games. My god, did I want to just quit at some point and I did not want to finish this one but I pushed through to complete and 117% this one. First off the Spyro sections are standard, levels once again have unique assets and enemies. These sections were totally on par with how the first two games were and I was very happy with them. I personally think the Rhynocs are weird and look silly and dumb, that's minimal. The villain is also just not great, I think she is just... Bleh. I was so mad at this game at some point that I took a very long break from it and forgot why I stopped, got on and immediately remembered the amount of aggravating stuff race back. Spyro sections were completely fine where it adds in the other characters who you can also play as is where I started losing it. It was fine when Spyro was using vehicles or otherwise but the other characters, please just no. I've looked at videos of this in the original version of this game as well and it was somehow worse at least gameplay wise. Sections with Sheila were fine, Sgt. Byrd was just boring as you became very overpowered in my opinion, Bentley is just a no, absolutely not, and Agent 9's levels were so all over the place and out of place I was just not interested or wanting to do them. There are also some levels with Hunter and they were also annoying but minimal compared to Bentley's. Some positives for this one are the boss fights at least end of area boss fights are very cool, some of the individual level boss fights are frustrating. Also, I get it was the 90's but skateboard sections, no. These bugged out for me on half the occasions I had to do them especially in the last section of the game I won because I fell through the map after a failed trick and it sent me ahead of the other racers and I won. This game also had me getting soft locked causing me to have to jump of the edges of the maps for a respawn to fix the puzzles. This happened a number of times so many that it was one of the things that originally made me take a break from the game. In the end it wasn't a terrible game, frustrating for me yes. Sometimes adding too much fluff to a game is too much especially if the fluff isn't executed in a productive way that still makes the game feel like its predecessors. 

Overall I was fairly happy with the entire collection aside from about a quarter of the third installment. I'm not sure if this was because a second studio was brought in to help with the third game or not, I'm unsure. The first and second games were a treat for me and so I'm sure that anyone with nostalgia towards the titles will love them. The third game has a sort of rushed feel at least to me but overall wasn't the worst, it is just the sections where I'm forced to play other characters that I didn't enjoy. Having other gameplay elements isn't an issue but the way these are done is just not up to a standard that makes them fun or enjoyable to me. The entire graphic overall with all three titles is amazing and the glow up from its PS1 era originals is outstanding. It was well worth my time and I played for quite awhile making nights after work enjoyable and relaxed. Its a great deal especially if it were to go on sale so I'd say pick it up at least for the first two installments and if you want to have a time go enjoy the third as well. The first two get an 8.5/ 10 for me because dragons are awesome and the third a 6.5/ 10 because no one likes Bentley's Boxing, just no.

143925101.review:
This is a fantastic collection of iconic games, even if I don't really have too many childhood memories with them.  Full disclosure: I was a Nintendo kid.  We had a GameCube, and my brother and I had our own DSes.  The only Spyro game I played when I was younger was A Hero's Tale, and I only remember the box art.  Throughout my early emulation kick, however, I was intrigued by the original Spyro trilogy.  I never made it very far in them though.  Playing through this game was the first time I had completed any of the original 3 games in this franchise.

Spyro 1 is a solid time.  It's fairly light on the plot side of things, but it makes up for it by being incredibly fun and having some iconic locations (for better and for worse).  This is the one I tend to go back to for some brain-off platforming, and with only a few exceptions, most levels won't be much of a challenge once you master the controls.  This remake also adds the Sparx radar function from later games to help hunt down some of the trickier gems.

Spyro 2 wound up being my favorite out of the collection, despite introducing Hunter into the series.  2 is a consistent ride.  Even the stuff I'm not the biggest fan of (something something trolley problem) is still fun in it's own way.  The music is great, the hub worlds are nice to explore, and I like the non-linear progression.  I might even develop a speedrun category for this one (Low% NG+).  This one is great!

Year of the Dragon was a step up in some ways, and a step down in others.  Expanding on the non-linearity of the last game is nice, and I like that the Speedways have more going on than in 2, but there were some ...decisions made that I disagree with.  I'm referring to the skateboard/hoverboard, those levels sucked.  The other playable characters brought some diversity into the gameplay without shoe-horning Spyro into more limited movesets temporarily.  Unlike the other 2 games in this pack, I haven't gone back to this one since getting 117%

The PC porting job is good for the most part.  I played with a DualShock 4 for the authentic experience.  I did run into some known issues trying to run the game at 60 FPS.  Due to a bug, some things like the staircase in the wizard level and the last jump in Tree Tops are impossible to clear at 60 or higher, so you have to go into the settings and set it to 30 FPS.  I wound up doing that in other parts of the game as well, so if you're wanting a solid 60 FPS experience, you won't find it here.

This game is good.

143313175.review:
Only completed the first game, but so far fun.


Few cons mostly performance/stability on the steam deck. Several times I hit spots where my fps just plummeted to around 2-3fps and lagging the entire game including the menu. Resaving the graphic settings would fix this.

Sometimes Spyro will just start sliding on the ground while standing still. Seems to be a somewhat common issue where setting a max fps limit (60) fixes this. Personally I had some serious problems in the dark passage level in the dreamweavers world where Spyro would just get stuck on random spots on the floor while walking. Jumping would fix this, but it would sometimes start doing it again right after. Lastly I had a few times where the game didnt seem like it registered I jumped so Spyro would just fall to his death. Ultimately setting the max fps limit seemed to fix most of my issues.

Couple minor things that aren't really issues, but are annoying enough. Flight controls(inverted) can't be changed for flight zones and the credits for the first game are about 20 min long with no way to skip or go to the menu. At no time do i ever want to watch 20 min worth of that crap. Leave it to the movie theatres where it belongs...

One last note is the steam deck verified process could be improved and made much more clear. From my experience the game itself was unstable at various times mostly in the dreamweavers and magic crafters worlds. Having to set an fps cap midway through a game kind of goes against the verified requirement of being playable with the default settings. Imo they should be doing is reevaluating games every few months to make sure newer updates or proton versions don't break anything to retain that verified status. Seems like once they set it as verified they almost never lower the status even if it technically shouldn't qualify for verified anymore. Thankfully this game only needed some minor change to be playable, but other games might be far worse.  So take verified with a grain of salt.

143125808.review:
I wanted to give this game a glowing recommendation but the PC version of the Reignited trilogy is just a buggy mess. I have this release on the Nintendo Switch and I had no problems whatsoever with it but I got it for PC because I figured it would be the better experience compared to the Switch's hardware. Boy was that a mistake.

I only played Spyro 1 but right out of the gate Spyro would not move when I pushed the thumbstick. He would animate as if he were walking, but he would not actually move anywhere. I would have to jump to get him unstuck from this state. It happened randomly throughout the entire playthrough and didn't seem specific to any level or world. Sometimes after walking and stopping Spyro would slowly slide on his own. If he slid off an edge he would fall and probably die, and I lost a few lives this way. Spyro also walks diagonally sometimes, for lack of a better way of describing it. He'll be facing one way but pull to the side as he walks and it makes navigating narrow bridges and platforms extremely hard. I also noticed a bug with the Supercharge ramps where sometimes Spyro will enter the Supercharge state but not have the speed that goes with it making certain levels like Tree Tops not possible to complete as long as this bug was in effect.

Also on top of that this game has at least one bugged achievement, Rocketeer in Spyro 1. I did exactly what the achievement said to do and it simply didn't unlock. There are only two points in the entire game where you can attempt this and one of them is at the very end after 100%'ing the game. I'm not planning on attempting it again. Not worth it.

Apparently a lot of these bugs can be fixed by setting the in-game FPS settings to 30 but I did not try this. I had already completed the majority of the game before I found this out. I shouldn't have to lower the FPS and like I said I was playing this on PC for the better experience compared to the Switch. There's no way the playtesters didn't notice the litany of glitches plaguing this game. They just simply didn't care. This is published by Activision after all so it's not like quality is their MO. Such a shame too because these were good games on the original PlayStation, but I guess I'm sticking to playing them on my original game discs because this collection is too jank to deal with. I'm not even going to bother playing the other two games.

142836275.review:
Nostalgia isn't the only thing holding this remaster up; it turns out that the original three Spyro games have stood the test of time and are still fun to play, even if it's your first time like it was for me.

Do be aware there's at least one moment in the Alpine Ridge level, where the framerate can cause a door to get stuck closed. Just go in to the menu and hit the 30fps limit for that one bit, and you're fine. I had no other issues playing this at a smooth 60fps for the entire trilogy.

These games do rather take on a childish feel in a lot of ways, the story of all three feels that way and mostly in the second game. I struggled a little bit with that as an adult, but hey if you can indulge in it then it's just fine.

The gameplay is where it's all at though. These are comprehensive collectathons with plenty of character to them. Whether it's dragons, eggs, keys, gems or orbs that you're searching for, everything feels exact and tailored to keep the gameplay pace well-tuned and quick. You're never too far away from the next thing to pick up, or little area to explore, or minor puzzle to solve.
There's not a lot of truly taxing or difficult stuff in any of the games, but the few examples of that are rather big. The dragon boss in Spyro 3, the jumping puzzle in Spyro 1's Tree Tops level and the various Hunter side-objectives in 2 & 3 being the main ones.
But pretty much all of this stuff is optional, so if you just want a laid-back approach to collecting a load of stuff, exploring all the worlds and flaming and charging all the baddies, you can absolutely have that and it's a lot of fun all-round.

The basic controls are smooth and responsive, while the camera is a bit slow to turn, there's a quick center-behind button as well. Running, charging, jumping, flaming and gliding all work great though and it does feel just right to do all these things.

The music and overall atmosphere are well defined in each world. Characters are generally funny and nicely animated, with attention to detail when expected. You can burn bits of the environment.

There's not a massive amount of things to say really, when the main appeal of these sorts of games is just HOW the controls feel - and it's just done very smoothly and nicely in the Reignited Trilogy. So if you want an experience that will last for somewhere near to 20 hours, that feels pretty good for the whole time, you can't go wrong with this pick.

Further thoughts, gameplay and a more in-depth review on my channel:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ag_-sQaDjV8

[h2]Short Game Description[/h2]
The Spyro Reignited Trilogy is a collection of Spyro the Dragon, Ripto's Rage!, and Year of the Dragon, but remakes and updates them to the actual graphics, with a great unique level design overall.
[list]
[*][h3]Positives[/h3]
Discussing the positives, first of all, the game gives so many hours of fun with many unique levels with their own setting accompanied by a great soundtrack, achieving great platform gameplay overall. Secondly, the game progression is well done; each game that you play, you get new mechanics that are not that repetitive while still maintaining the original essence. Thirdly, there were unique enemies and bosses that made the game even more challenging, despite the platform scenarios.
[*][h3]Negatives[/h3]
On the negative side, the main flaw was that the boss fights were very clunky because Spyro's movement was somewhat awful most of the time. Besides that, the game does not work properly at high FPS, bringing some non-completable levels until you lower the FPS limit to 30 or 50.
[/list][h2][u]Conclusion[/u][/h2]
In short, it's a remaked trilogy that brings great level design, an awesome soundtrack, and challenging platform scenarios, but sadly functions badly sometimes at high FPS with awful gameplay at bosses. The game is a 7.75/10.

142605628.review:
Yes. I obviously recommend this game.

If my profile didn't make it abundantly clear, this is one of my all-time favorite childhood series. I was never really that into Crash Bandicoot. Linear gameplay is fine, but not for me with platforming, since it takes all of the fun away from exploration and puts it more into challenging you with carefully timed jumps in limited spaces.

Spyro's not like that, it's much more relaxed. There are some challenges, to be sure, especially with the mini-games in Spyro 2 and Spyro 3, but technically you don't have to 100% (or 117% or whatever) the games just to beat them, you'll just miss out on the bonus levels in 1 and 3 or the permanent superflame powerup in 2. Even then there's some wiggle room, since you can still access the bonus areas in 2 and 3 without getting everything.

Anyway, the Reignited Trilogy being a total from-the-ground-up remake of the original trilogy of Spyro games, it works very hard to create a faithful experience... in terms of gameplay. There are actually a lot of aesthetic choices I wasn't too pleased about in the days counting up to the release of the games, and unfortunately Spyro 3 might be a little [i] too [i/] faithful to the original because Activision was directly responsible for it being rushed AGAIN, causing issues with the whole Reignited Trilogy that, while mostly fixed, will probably mar this otherwise shining example of how a remake should be done.

For long-time fans, look past the changes and appreciate it for what it is: a recreation of a childhood classic. Even full-price at $40 it's a steal.

For new fans: you would be stupid to miss out on this if you like collectathon mascot platformers. Spyro's the best and you won't get a word in on me about that edgewise.

Oh and hey, play with mods once you've beaten the game. Model swap Spyro out for Cinder if you want, it's your game to play how you like... and while it's certainly buggy to play as Sgt. Byrd in Artisans or Bentley in Glimmer, as the levels weren't designed with them in mind and sometimes their attacks can't even hurt enemies, it's still a heck of a lot of fun. Especially if, like me, you always wished you could do that as a kid.

142572436.review:
A Fiery Remake: Spyro Reignited Trilogy

Score: 8.8/10

Developed by Toys for Bob and published by Activision, the Spyro Reignited Trilogy is a lovingly crafted remaster of the three original PlayStation classics: Spyro the Dragon, Spyro 2: Ripto's Rage, and Spyro: Year of the Dragon. Successfully maintaining the essence of the original titles while revamping them for a modern audience, the trilogy deserves a commendable score of 8.8 out of 10.

The Reignited Trilogy is a heartwarming trip down memory lane, maintaining the sense of whimsy, adventure, and humor that defined the originals. The captivating tales of a young dragon on heroic quests hold up remarkably well, thanks to the timeless charm of the characters and the engaging nature of the stories.

The original controls and gameplay mechanics have been faithfully reproduced, ensuring that each glide, flame, and charge feels just as satisfying as in the original games. The inclusion of quality-of-life improvements, like the option to use an analogue stick to control Spyro, demonstrates the developers' dedication to balancing nostalgic gameplay with modern conveniences.

Visually, the Reignited Trilogy is a delight. The graphical overhaul breathes new life into the Spyro universe, with richly detailed environments, impressive lighting effects, and meticulously designed characters that stay true to their original designs while being distinctly modern. The developers have gone the extra mile to ensure that each world is unique and immersive, offering a vibrant and colorful playground for players to explore.

In terms of audio, the remastered soundtrack by Stewart Copeland, the original composer, is a highlight. The catchy, atmospheric tunes, coupled with improved sound effects and voice acting, elevate the overall experience significantly.

One of the Trilogy's most impressive aspects is the sheer amount of content on offer. With three full games, over 100 levels, and myriad collectibles, the Trilogy provides excellent value for money. Whether you're battling bosses, rescuing fellow dragons, or participating in challenging mini-games, there's plenty to keep you engaged for hours on end.

However, the Trilogy is not without its minor faults. Some players might find certain aspects of the games, such as the flight controls and camera movement, a bit clunky, even with the updates. Additionally, a few of the more dated game design elements, like the lack of a map in the first game, might be off-putting to players used to more contemporary conveniences.

In conclusion, the Spyro Reignited Trilogy is a fantastic homage to a beloved classic that stands as an example of how to do remasters right. With its nostalgic charm, appealing visuals, engaging gameplay, and substantial content, the Trilogy is not just for fans of the original games, but also for newcomers looking for a fun and accessible platformer. Despite its minor shortcomings, it serves as a vibrant and rewarding journey that any player can enjoy.

Gallo Pinto Costarricense

Ingredientes
3 cucharadas de aceite de canola
1/4 cebolla picada
1/2 pimiento verde (o rojo) en cuadraditos
3 tazas de frijoles rojos o negros, cocidos
3 tazas de arroz blanco, cocido
1. pizca de Sal
2 cucharadas de culantro picado

Instrucciones
1. Calienta el aceite en una sartén grande y fríe la cebolla y el pimiento hasta que estén suaves.
2. Agrega los frijoles, bien escurridos, y fríe de tres a cinco minutos. Agrega un poco del caldo de cocción, si ves que están quedando muy secos.
3. Incorpora el arroz y sigue friendo unos tres minutos más agregando un poco más de caldo de frijoles para que el gallo pinto no quede muy seco y finalmente adorna con culantro picado.

¡Pura Vida!

For those who haven't played Spyro, you explore different worlds as a little dragon, collecting gems and whatever else the plot wants you to get (free frozen dragons, collect orbs, free baby dragons from eggs). You can glide around (and fly in flying levels), use a flame or charge attack. It has mostly simple gameplay yet later games introduce more abilities and 'mini-games', puzzles, or challenges in the levels. Irreverent humor throughout yet compared to most modern games perhaps, the plot and characters are NOT complex at all and have not much more deeper meaning than "collect and rescue." Reignited looks so beautiful from the level backgrounds to everything else. I LOVE the redesign of the dragons in Spryo 1 -- they are so creative! There are a few redesigns in game 3 I've seen which are... a little creepy... trying to stay too close to the original with the pixel black eyes. Overall it's a solid game; lots of fun. It's nice I got this on sale so 3 games for $9.99 ain't bad at all!

141625242.review:
This remastered trilogy of the original games was clearly done with not only the intent to maintain the essence of the originals, but also homogenize and improve them. 

The game looks beautiful, with the updated models and voice acting being excellent. Having the dragons each have their own unique models and personality compared to the original, as well as implementing Spark being able to detect gems across all three games unlike the original games was a terrific improvement. The menu selection and guidebook make it incredibly easy to switch between games at will, although I did notice longer than expected loading screens at times. 

The gameplay is pretty much exactly what you would expect from Spyro. It’s simplistic platforming revolved around collecting and exploring the levels, as well as minigames with the later series entries. The biggest issue was both the camera and movement, which often felt less sharp than in the original games. This was most notable during underwater and flight levels. There were times I would have to switch from my controller to a mouse and keyboard in order to have Spyro turn sharp enough to make specific turns. I also encountered small bugs that were not detrimental and easily fixable by resetting the level, but did come as a hindrance at times, such as whirlwinds not allowing me to glide or being stuck in specific mobs. 

9 / 10

141437593.review:
Classic Spyro! Reignited for the modern age! This trilogy brings back our purple hero Spyro and his buddy Sparx from the iconic classic Playstation games Spyro the Dragon, Spyro 2: Ripto's Rage and Spyro: Year of the Dragon. The perfect collection for any fan of the game, even if just for nostalgia's sake, this will take you back in time to when you were playing these games in the late 90's and 00's. Everything is perfect about this, from the graphics to the music, which you can make the choice between the reignited game music or the classic. Animations and character designs are beautiful, as is every world you step, or rather, glide into. Full of colour and wonder.

Being a long-time fan of Spyro since he came flying into our lives in 1998 and kindling an ember in our hearts, I've fully completed this on Playstation 4 already after having got it on release. I couldn't say no to re-buying the trilogy again on Steam, because not only am I a sucker for everything that this game is, but I love that you can collect the items in the points shop, as well as show off your achievements here (I mean sure, you get achievements on Playstation too, but I value them more on Steam.). You can also mod the game, which I haven't done yet, but will soon, just to play around with what creators have made, but the game really is perfect even without that. It works naturally with a Playstation Dualshock 4, so you don't have to mess around in Steam settings to get it to show Playstation icons instead of XBOX or PC. 

I bought this in the trio collection along with Crash N.Sane Trilogy and Crash 4: It's About Time, but at the sale price of £8.74 (compared to £34.99) you are crazy to not buy this. You'll have hours of fun, whether you've played Spyro before or not. Fantastic games, fantastic music, fantastic characters and worlds. It's just all amazing. Get it.

141228958.review:
~ If you didn't know: click the left analog stick to find missing gems. ~

Yes I recommend it as a whole, even after my upcoming rant. But this is gonna be long because I need catharsis after Spyro 3.

I only owned Spyro 1 as a kid so the other two games were fairly new to me on Reignited Trilogy.

I liked the redesign for the most part (yet the originals will always have their own charm).
The camera controls were just awful though. Active mode, passive mode - both were bad, in my opinion. You have to manually control it just to see where you're going sometimes. 

Now onto the individual games:
Spyro 1 was as lovely as ever. Fun collectathon game.

Spyro 2 was great, too. Minigames are introduced so there are more things to do in each level, but it's nothing too troublesome.
EXCEPT for Gulp. Eff you, Gulp.

Now I need to vent about Spyro 3. I was not prepared for the frustration that game caused me.

100% gem collection was painful in certain levels. More than a few times I was missing the final gems and they were in hidden places or I had just not scoured every single piece of ground. Icy Peak and Spooky Swamp were the worst for that. It was only after a while that I saw on Reddit that you can click the left stick and Sparx points to where the missing gems are. If it wasn't for that, I would have wasted even more time in later levels. (It also says it on the controls menu, so silly me for not realising!)

Had I played Spyro 3 before, this might not have been an issue. What is unavoidable, though, is the design of some of the minigames. They are just [i]unfair[/i].

The fire dragons in Fireworks Factory, holy hell, WHO thought of that? It takes forever to kill them [i]and[/i] they can regain health. What a slog.

The whack-a-mole game with Bentley....... The amount of times I swore at that blasted game. The timer starts before you can even move yourself down the stairs (with the speed of a turtle) and because of the camera you can't even see where you are supposed to hit. And the DAMN GNOMES RUNNING IN YOUR WAY LIKE HEADLESS CHICKENS. WHY ARE YOU HERE?!

Then, the skateboarding. Once you get used to the mechanics it's not so bad but then they introduced skateboarding races in Lost Fleet and, bloody hell, it's time to get angry at skateboarding again. It's so easy to crash when you are trying to do flips; sometimes Spyro will just fly off course into the celestial sphere; and the turbo meter randomly decides when to fill - sometimes giving you zero boost. It's just so inconsistent in every aspect.

It's worth watching some videos on the skateboarding, because that helped me get the Lost Fleet skill point.

Apparently those three games mentioned above are harder in the remake compared to the original. I fully believe it.
They were the main culprits, but in general a lot of the side character missions/extra tasks were not really as fun as the previous two games. They felt slow.

I just wanted Spyro 3 to be [i]over[/i], a feeling which I was not expecting. I never had that frustration with Spyro 2, and certainly not with Spyro 1. It's one thing having a few moments of challenge here and there, but to litter a game with infuriating mechanics and easy-to-miss gems is just annoying.

Right at the end, after all the hard work, is a bonus area. What a nice reward! And guess what: it also has another skateboarding race for you to enjoy!

* scream *

140939769.review:
Spyro the Dragon 62% completion 

Spyro Reignited is a flawless remaster of a high-octane PS1 platformer. The updated visuals look phenomenal and do an excellent job of capturing the 90's charm of the original games. The games themselves are an absolute pleasure to navigate moment-to-moment, although some elements like instant-death pits and a lives system did not age as well as the movement.

The focus on horizontal speed does make exploring a bit unsatisfying: the game feels best when you're charging along at a breakneck speed, but careful exploration requires a more methodical approach. Navigating small spaces also feels finicky compared to games like Crash Bandicoot and Mario 64. In particular the flying levels required an obnoxious level of precise muscle memory. For pure flow-state fun Spyro has aged incredibly well, but it couldn't sustain my interest over the long term.

140869718.review:
This game is a fantastic collection that brings back our beloved dragon in a whole new light. This remastered version of the three classic Spyro games offers stunning graphics, improved gameplay, and a nostalgic trip down memory lane.

[list]
[*] Graphics:
[b]First and foremost, the visuals in Spyro are absolutely breathtaking.[/b] The developers have done an incredible job of revamping the original graphics, giving them a modern and vibrant touch. The environments are richly detailed, and the characters are beautifully rendered, making the game a joy to look at.

One of the standout features of Spyro Reignited Trilogy is its charming and quirky characters. From Spyro himself to his trusty dragonfly companion Sparx, each character is full of personality and brings a unique element to the game. The voice acting is top-notch, adding an extra layer of immersion to the experience.

[*] Gameplay:
[b]In terms of gameplay, this game stays true to the original games[/b] while adding some much-needed improvements. The controls are responsive and smooth, allowing for precise movements and enjoyable exploration. The levels have been faithfully recreated, offering a mix of platforming challenges, puzzle-solving, and exciting boss battles.

However, it's worth noting that the difficulty level in the game may not appeal to everyone. While the game is generally accessible and enjoyable for players of all ages, some sections can be challenging, especially for younger or less experienced gamers. Nevertheless, this adds to the sense of accomplishment when overcoming obstacles and completing levels.

[*] Audio:
[b]The soundtrack ingame is simply outstanding.[/b] The remastered versions of the original tracks capture the essence of the classic games while adding a fresh and modern twist. The music perfectly complements the gameplay, creating an immersive and nostalgic atmosphere.
[/list]

In conclusion, Spyro Reignited Trilogy is a must-have for fans of the original games and newcomers alike. With its stunning visuals, improved gameplay, memorable characters, and nostalgic soundtrack, it successfully revitalizes the classic Spyro experience for a new generation of players. Whether you're reliving childhood memories or discovering Spyro for the first time, this trilogy offers hours of fun and adventure. It's a big yes pour me.

140719653.review:
Spyro Reignited Trilogy is, in my opinion, one of the best games ever made. I have a personal connection to the franchise, as I played the original version of Spyro when it was released, despite its pixelated and less visually appealing graphics. However, even back then, I fell in love with the game and its charming protagonist.

There's something about Spyro that captivates me, although I can't quite put my finger on it. Perhaps it's the sense of adventure and exploration that comes with guiding the lovable purple dragon through beautifully designed worlds. Maybe it's the satisfying feeling of collecting gems, rescuing other dragons, and thwarting the plans of the mischievous villains. Whatever the reason, Spyro has always held a special place in my heart.

For those who haven't experienced the original Spyro games, I wholeheartedly recommend purchasing the Spyro Reignited Trilogy. One of the fantastic aspects of this package is that you get not one, but three incredible games in a single purchase. The trilogy includes Spyro the Dragon, Spyro 2: Ripto's Rage!, and Spyro: Year of the Dragon, each offering its own unique set of challenges, characters, and environments.

The developers behind the Reignited Trilogy, Toys for Bob, have done a remarkable job in revitalizing the franchise. The updated graphics are absolutely stunning, breathing new life into the vibrant and colorful worlds of Spyro. The attention to detail is evident in every aspect, from the lush landscapes to the character animations. It truly feels like stepping into a magical realm.

Not only do you get to relive the nostalgia of the original Spyro games with enhanced visuals, but the Reignited Trilogy also includes quality-of-life improvements and modernized controls. These enhancements make the gameplay smoother and more enjoyable, ensuring that both newcomers and longtime fans can appreciate the trilogy to the fullest.

Whether you're a fan of the original games or someone looking to embark on a fantastic adventure, Spyro Reignited Trilogy is a worthwhile purchase. With its charming protagonist, engaging gameplay, and the value of three games in one, it offers hours of delightful entertainment. I can confidently say that this trilogy is a must-have for anyone seeking a memorable and enjoyable gaming experience.

I would, without a doubt in my mind, recommend this remaster to anyone who´s played and enjoyed the original Spyro trilogy and all the others who love platformers aka jump´n´runs and collectathons.

The levels are beautifully designed but stay true to the originals. The controls feel on point, which is important for a platformer.
There are miniscule changes in some cutscenes, to make the game feel more up to date for todays kids, but other than that it is a very well written love letter to the original trilogy.

The game runs exceptionally well, even on low end hardware like an AMD Ryzen 3 3200G paired with a GTX 1650.

I can either play it with consistent 60 fps @ 720p or consistent 30 fps @ 1080p. All maxed out of course, except for for motion blur and antialiasing, which I never use in any game.

I suggest you set it to 30 fps or unlimited though, as otherwise you will encounter a bug in certain levels, which will hinder you from progressing.

It´s the only bug I´ve encountered and I am more than half way through.
It appears as though the developers don´t intend to fix this bug, but I suppose one can live with that as the game runs just fine otherwise.

The remastered Trilogy is well worth the money, in my humble opinion. I don´t regret buying it, at all.

140297882.review:
Spyro Reignited is a loving remake of the original 3 Spyro games for Playstation (PS1). If you loved those, you'll love Reignited.

While I love how faithful the Reignited remakes are, I do have some gripes. They can be a wee bit jarring between games, mostly in how dialogue and cutscenes are handled noticeably differently in each of the 3 games. While certain things such as the Baby Dragons in Spyro 3 have lost some of their original uniqueness from the PS1 Spyro 3 (I feel this is when Dev time started to run out) and some minor designs (such as enemy weapons) have seen "softer" designs for age rating reasons with little consistency.

Being on PC also has the extra of playing with mods, which means most importantly playable Cynder (which if modded right, is almost seamless apart from some cutscene weirdness (again, varies massively by game) and NPCs saying Spyro (but given they usually give off a sub-brick intelligence vibe, this just came off as funny).

139980990.review:
Honestly speaking there isn't a single thing I can really say about the original Spyro trilogy that isn't overtly biased and blinded by pure nostalgia. Not a day goes by where I can see this game and not immediately think of being a little kid and sitting on the floor next to my brother in awe as he played and then waiting on him to come visit so I could show him that I learned how to do the cool flips on the skateboard to catch the little guys on balloons. At the time I absolutely despised the sounds of the egg thieves and hearing them in the original trailer literally brought me to tears.

This remake absolutely blew my expectations out of the water. I may not have a decent amount of playtime into the Steam version but I finished the PS4 edition (PS1 nostalgia so it was the obvious choice to play on originally) not long after launch and grabbed this one on sale just to replay it on PC and it is still just as flawless as the PS4 version. The remastered music is wonderful, the option to toggle it makes it perfect. The remade bosses and important dragons all having their own distinct characteristics.  I literally cannot state just how impressed I was (and still am) with this remake. There was so much love and care put into bringing our little purple dragon back into the modern day.

Every time I replay these 3 games even in their remastered form I get immediately thrown right back into my childhood and that is such a wonderful thing. I do not think any other remake to this point or in the near future will ever come close to the sheer perfection of this one. ♥
