139882544.review:
If you're a fan of classic platformers and have a soft spot for nostalgic adventures, then Spyro The Reignited Trilogy is an absolute must-play. Developed by Toys for Bob, this remaster pays homage to the iconic purple dragon's original games while infusing them with stunning visual upgrades and modern enhancements. While the magic of the original titles may be hard to replicate, The Reignited Trilogy offers an unforgettable journey that will captivate both newcomers and die-hard fans. Get ready to soar through beautifully redesigned worlds and relive the excitement of Spyro's escapades. With its impressive graphics, faithful gameplay, and nostalgic charm, this remaster scores a solid 10/10.

Visual Splendor That Will Leave You Breathless:
Prepare to have your eyes dazzled! Spyro The Reignited Trilogy boasts a jaw-dropping visual overhaul that truly breathes new life into the dragon's universe. The remastered graphics are a feast for the senses, with vibrant colors, detailed environments, and meticulously crafted character models. Whether you're exploring lush landscapes or diving into sparkling caverns, each location is brought to life with stunning detail and artistic flair. The Reignited Trilogy manages to strike the perfect balance between modern visuals and the original art style, resulting in a truly mesmerizing experience that will make you appreciate Spyro's world like never before.

Gameplay That Feels as Smooth as Ever:
Great visuals are one thing, but what about the gameplay? Fear not, because The Reignited Trilogy faithfully recreates the mechanics that made the original games so beloved. Controlling Spyro is an absolute delight, with precise and responsive controls that make every jump, glide, and fire-breathing moment feel satisfyingly smooth. The level design stays true to the classics while incorporating modern enhancements, offering a perfect blend of nostalgia and fresh surprises. Whether you're tackling enemies, collecting gems, or completing challenging platforming sections, Spyro's gameplay is a true testament to timeless fun.

Unleashing Nostalgia with Every Note:
Remember the nostalgic soundtracks that accompanied Spyro's adventures? Well, get ready for a trip down memory lane. The Reignited Trilogy features a remastered soundtrack composed by Stewart Copeland, the original composer of the Spyro games. Each track flawlessly captures the essence of the original melodies, evoking a powerful wave of nostalgia that will transport you back to your gaming roots. The attention to detail in recreating the audio experience is commendable and adds an extra layer of immersion, making the remastered trilogy a heartwarming journey for both old fans and newcomers.

Spyro 1: ☆☆☆⋆

Tiene sus cosas de juego antiguo que me hacen alejarme de él, pero pocas en comparación a otros juegos de la época. Me ha costado un suplicio controlar los saltos, pero al final lo hice y me lo he sacado 120%. No se siente repetitivo aunque yo pensaba que se me iba a hacer así y eso es bueno. Su punto bajo son las peleas de boses y a veces lo lineal de sus niveles. Por lo demás, no me ha parecido para nada mal juego, aunque lo que he jugado del dos, ya me parece mejor que todo este juego. 


Spyro 2: ☆☆☆☆⋆

Creo que se ha convertido en uno de mis juegos favoritos, por lo menos en el Top 10. La mejora respecto al primero es considerable, el añadido de misiones para conseguir los orbes lo hace muy bien. Los bosses siguen siendo chiquis pero la pelea de Gulp; la madre que me parió, encima buggeada. Me ha gustado muchísimo más de lo que esperaba. Me gusto mucho los diseños, menos los del tigre y la fauno, pero los niveles están guays, lo de que haya poderes que desbloqueas mas adelante y tengas que volver a completar niveles también. No se, no es un 10, pero para mi creo que cerca de un 9. Definitivamente un juegardo.

Spyro 3: ☆☆☆⋆

Se me ha hecho bola, además desde el principio. Pretende ser el segundo, intentado mejorar pero lo que hace es ser peor que el anterior creo que en todos los aspectos, historia, diseño de mapas, misiones... Los minijuegos me parecen la peor decisión del juego, el skate... Lo unico bueno que puedo decir de esto es que los mapas de rutas son mucho mejores que en los demás juegos, y las batallas de los bosses también, pero las misiones de Cazador son para pegarse un tiro en los cojones.

139567679.review:
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
   [*] +Amazing graphics
   [*] +Three Spyro game remakes are included, meaning there’s a good amount of content to play through
   [*] +Good gameplay
   [*] +The gem finder ability (available in all three games) makes finding gems in levels much easier
[/list]
 
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
   [*] -The third game did not seem as good as the first two, but it was still decent
   [*] -There were times when I could not control the camera even though I should have been able to
   [*] -Physics is tied to fps. If your fps is very high, such as 144 fps, certain physics are affected, such as your max jump height. This can be a problem in certain areas, meaning you have to temporarily cap your fps to something low, such as 30 fps, in order to complete what you want to do.
[/list]
 
[b]Comments[/b]
Spyro: Reignited Trilogy consist of remakes of three Spyro games, which are Spyro the Dragon, Spyro 2: Ripto’s Rage and Spyro: Year of the Dragon. I have never played these games before, so the Reignited Trilogy was my first time experiencing these games. I enjoyed playing through all three games, though I did not like the third game as much as the first two. The only major complaint I have about the Trilogy is that having a high fps can affect certain physics. For example, there is one area in Spyro the Dragon where if your fps is too high, you won’t be able to make a jump since your max jump height is affected by the high fps. I had to cap my fps to 30 in order to get past this area. Thankfully, there were only a handful of times where I had to do this.

Overall, if you are into platformers and have never played the original Spyro trilogy, I recommend taking a look at this game, especially if it’s on sale. If you have played the original Spyro Trilogy, it may still be worth taking a look at this game.

I really enjoyed the first game but the second and third are just painful. Which since the first is so short its hard to recommend this trilogy.

It feels like they have tried to overcompensate for the first game being short by wasting your time. Things like having too many gems to gather and spread out to literally every corner of every map just makes it tedious to play. E.G instead of having gems up the middle of some steps you have to jump up, they are on opposing sides so you need to jump left, right, left, right. Another example are the random mini games that ask you to do the same thing 5 times for the sake of it. Really, the same thing 5 times in a row?

The mechanics in game 2 and 3 also feel terrible. Swimming is clunky as hell and the mechanic to run, jump, glide, then flap at the last second just adds to the horrible feeling of tedium. Run, jump, glide is plenty of things to control to get a perfect jump adding the flap on top of that doesn't feel rewarding. 

Each point is minor, but add it all up and it just feels terrible to play games 2 and 3. 

The graphics do look nice and overall the port is good although there are some minor bugs. So really this is a gripe about the original games.

139334437.review:
This game is everything a remake should be.

It's a straight-up modernisation of a classic that stays true to the original game while upgrading the graphics to an incredible standard.

Highly recommended.

---

A few minor quibbles, will update as I play:

- Sparx' point to gems ability is now always available, which means that one of the Sparx Worlds now gives you no reward.
- There is seemingly no joystick deadzone in the menus which makes them difficult to navigate with a gamepad (when I release the stick, it often flicks back in the opposite direction).
- Aiming works on toggle now instead of on hold; you can't tap triangle to recenter your view anymore.
- You can't invert the cannon / first-person aiming controls.
- The glide/hover mechanics feel a *little* bit different. It's a lot harder to perform a hover on flat ground now, often when I press triangle it just seems to abort my glide.
- The skateboard controls a little differently; it seems much easier to accidentally end up facing backwards after performing a trick, and colliding with walls during a race is much less forgiving.
- Resetting after a death is a little slow - it shows a transition screen every time instead of just a dip-to-black.
- I find Spyro's new texture a little too vibrant / over-saturated. He used to be more of a medium purple (#9370DB) but now he is VERY purple (#800080).
- Many challenges have been made easier (e.g. through auto-aim), while other parts have been made MUCH harder (e.g. fighting Gulp). This is not necessarily a bad thing - just an observation really.
- The snowball-throwers in Frozen Altars no longer moon Spyro.
- After Bentley's Outpost, a cutscene played without any audio.

Many bugs have also been reported on the Steam discssions, but sadly none will ever be fixed because the game is no longer maintained. Such a shame.

I remember playing first spyro long time ago, but I never completed it.

I enjoyed first game alot, it was just like I remembered it. The reignited brings the same feeling, but in fresh graphics. The only bug was with green guys, the fix was to set fps to 30.

Second game was ... interesting. New mechanics and characters added alot, but challenges were underwhelming and just boring. Copy and paste of never ending tutorial, nothing special really. This is just an homage to old game, because everything was recreated as it was in old days.

The third game ... damn, I was sad It ended so quick. It combines first game with second and plays really well. Playing with spyro friends, unique side activities, actual history progress gave the purpose to worlds. The only drawback was difficulty of bosses, in comparison some rhinos were much deadlier :D In this part sparx missions were bugged for me and I could complete them at the end (and I missed actual good upgrades to Spyro, but hey I didnt know)

I 100% the whole trilogy and It was not that challenging, but fun to run around and relax.

Enemies wouldn't register a flame or charge hit on occasion, one of the tank missions, the tank wouldn't even drive forward normally (I had to fire the gun and spam left and right bumper to move slightly), Sparx would stop automatically picking up gems on and off or ignore butterfly when she was on low health, and one slide puzzle couldn't be completed on controller because Spyro wouldn't turn fast enough, so I had to switch to keyboard and mouse. The skateboard missions had my skateboard breaking at the top of ramps and Spyro would randomly change direction when landing a trick throwing me off the edge off a cliff, enemies wouldn't appear in bonus missions and required a full restart, T-posing enemies too. 138636494.review:
Durante la década de los '90s, el género de los plataformas fue uno de los que mayor auge tuvo junto a la creación de personajes que sirvieran a modo de mascotas. La quinta generación de consolas es un buen ejemplo de ello, época donde nació el carismático dragón púrpura de nombre Spyro bajo el ala de Insomniac Games. Si bien la saga pasó por varias manos tras la trilogía original y no tuvo una evolución clara ni tampoco buena con entregas más mediocres que la inteligencia de un gnorc, los chicos de Toys for Bob fueron los encargados de traer de regreso las aventuras del intrépido dragoncito en toda su gloria.

A grandes rasgos, este remake es un calco prácticamente intacto de los juegos de PlayStation con variantes muy puntuales. Visualmente es más bello que nunca, haciendo gala de unos efectos preciosos tipo cell shading donde no sólo Spyro se ve bastante bien diseñado y fiel a sus entregas originales; todos los personajes cuentan con un nivel de animaciones, detalles en sus rediseños y expresividad sublimes haciéndolos más adorables que nunca. El mismo patrón se repite con los niveles, todos cuidados al milímetro en términos de tamaño, elementos que conforman el escenario y enemigos, siendo bastante reminiscentes a la trilogía original. El mimo y cariño puesto incluso en los apartados más decorativos, como que cada nivel cuenta con un fondo exclusivo en la pantalla de carga, los múltiples efectos que dan vida a los escenarios, o la galería que muestra el arte conceptual de la trilogía hacen del juego una experiencia muy agradable. La gran fidelidad de la que goza el título, similar a la que tiene Spyro con el pequeño Sparx, podría ser, no obstante, un arma de doble filo ya que Reignited Trilogy es una gran recreación de las aventuras de los noventas sin sorpresa alguna para los veteranos, haciendo de los tres juegos una revisita muy deleitosa aunque con muy poca novedad.

Al tratarse de una trilogía compacta, en términos de jugabilidad es, a grandes rasgos, la misma a lo largo de los tres juegos lo cual sacrifica un poco la sensación de evolución que hizo Insomniac con sus obras, puesto que dispondremos desde el comienzo todo el set de movimiento básicos de Spyro desde el primero hasta el tercero. No obstante, el título goza del espíritu de los juegos de antaño donde la diversión prioriza por encima de todo lo demás, de modo que aunque a la larga puede hacerse un tanto repetitiva la dinámica jugable, en el fondo es una aventura extremadamente entretenida de jugar tanto por su sencillez y objetivos mayormente claros como por la implementación, cada vez mayor, de minijuegos y tareas nuevas conforme se avanza de modo que el juego resulte siempre entretenido.

No obstante, no existe tal cosa como una obra perfecta. Reignited Trilogy padece de cierta inestabilidad en su tasa de fotogramas que se hace muy notorio durante las pantallas de carga, aunque por suerte nunca durante el gameplay. Así pues, la cámara en determinados enfrentamientos contra jefes sigue un patrón que puede chocar con la jugabilidad haciendo un poco difícil manejar a Spyro a pesar de las configuraciones en el menú. La banda sonora presenta elementos interesantes como un dinamismo en su uso dependiendo de las acciones del protagonista, además de contar con una regrabación orquestal de las composiciones la cual cumple a nivel musical en comparación con las versiones MIDI de PS1, aunque careciendo de la misma fuerza, energía y vigor que éstas gozaban. No obstante, este apartado puede ser modificado en cualquier momento a gusto del jugador, añadiendo opciones muy cómodas como la selección inmediata de niveles que aceleran el proceso de ir de una zona ya visitada a otra.

En definitiva, Spyro Reignited Trilogy es una verdadera carta de amor al pasado, una recreación de la trilogía de Insomniac cuidada con fervor y ahínco, y toda una oda a las aventuras clásicas de la quinta generación. Aunque se ve ligeramente empañado por sus pequeños defectos técnicos y uso de cámara, este juego sigue la estela de los remakes más fidedignos hechos al igual que los de Crash Bandicoot o MediEvil; obras inmortales traídas a la actualidad con más alicientes que el simple recuerdo para disfrutarlas como los infantes de antaño.

138515106.review:
The Reignited Trilogy does a great job at making the original Spyro games more accessible on modern systems, but it doesn't add any value to them (beside the upgraded graphics) and, in some respect, even makes them worse.

The first game is fantastic. It directly involves the dragon world, the dialogues with the adult dragons add to its lore, the level design is simple but good and collecting dragon eggs is fun. There are some issues with the camera sometimes breaking.

The second game strips away all of that. It takes place outside the dragon world, you don't even collect dragons anymore (if I remember correctly), the level design is usually fine but starts really suffering from weird collisions and boss fights that straight up break when your framerate is too high (!!!). And with "high" I mean more than 30 FPS.

Spyro 3 goes more into the direction of Spyro 1 again, but the levels feel simpler and the gameplay issues become more apparent. The controls also completely bug out in some minigames such as the skateboarding. The unlockable characters add some gameplay variety but are underused and the ending of the game, including the final boss and related cutscenes, just feel absolutely lazy. Apparently it was outsourced to a different company and butchered more than the prequels.

While I was trying to reach an unreachable platform in Spyro 3, I finally figured out that you jump higher when capping the framerate to 30 FPS. Other people report doors in the game not opening when the framerate is too high, or Spyro just constantly sliding on the ground. All those issues have been known for years and got never addressed by Toys for Bob (was there even a single patch for this game?), but some NPCs do the floss dance from Fortnite, so that's something, right? The same devs developed Crash 4 - figures.

Emulate the PS1 games or something if you're not too lazy. But only 60% of players actually made it through the first world of Spyro 1, so I guess you'll likely enjoy the remake too without ever reaching the broken parts. I'll give it a thumb up anyway because it worked for the most part and it was good enough for me to play until 100% completion (or 120%/100%/117% if you're a Spyro nerd), but maybe for the first time I'm not tempted to collect the remaining achievements in a game I completed.

138259520.review:
I've never played any of the Spyro games, so I went into this blind. I was happily surprised to see these games were not nostalgia bait and quite fun.

[list]
[*]The art team nailed their work, the locations are nicely designed and varied through the games. 
[*]The platforming feels nice and fluid. Some rounded edges on platforms can turn near-miss landings into a slide into the abyss but it's a rare issue.
[*]The combat is simplistic in a good way; this game is a platformer first and foremost so the combat is simple and easy to learn.
[*]Saving dragons in the first two games is fun since each dragon has a unique design and voice lines, which is sadly lost in the third game, saving eggs with repeating animations and no voice acting.
[*]The side characters are hit-or-miss, but the unique levels given to each of them in the third game adds a nice bit of variety to the levels
[*]The bosses were a bit of a letdown, even the final bosses, but ultimately they're a footnote.
[/list]

The only thing these games lack is a difficulty curve near the end, but they don't necessarily need one either. The games are a fun & easy glide most of the way through.

Ultimately these games were quite fun to 100%. it's rare for gems to be so out of the way that they're hard to find on your second run through a level, although some of them are easy to miss. Some of the achievements require actions outside your normal 100%, but most of them will be picked up automatically while playing through the game and picking up all the gems, so you won't have to do much more to comb through what you've missed.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

'Speedway Minigame' - Flying through circles won't register at times....triggering a restart.

'Speedway Minigame' - Sometimes burning objects won't register the object being burnt, Triggering a restart.
*Sometimes I restart a time trial over 10 times because the speedway Minigame doesn't burn my targets.

'Spyro 3' - Hitting literally anything with Yeti in Spyro 3 at times wont register.

*I'll mention that Spyros flame is super inconsistent, some say it's a shorter flame compared to Original. It either hits or misses especially

'Movement controls' -  are inverted for Minigames AND CANNOT BE CHANGED [b](For the invert fix check the guide section for the workaround, Thanks spyro community)[/b]

TO ADD TO THE CONTROLS - There is no Sensitivity for Game pads. Only Mouse and Keyboard. :/// Yes you can do this externally but really...

where percision is needed

137622387.review:
I love this game! Retro meets modern, loads of fun, very visually appealing, with easy to use controls for a computer. Also comes with the abilty to remap keys if you like, and the play with a controller. 

The story line is interesting, yet brief enough to allow gameplay to dominate. Much of the game is easy enough nearly anyone can manage it, but if you are a completionist, there are several places for an extreme challenge, while also not completely getting in the way of the main game. Highly recommended!

There are a few not so great things to mention. Final boss fights are all very tough, as there are no checkpoints, great flight skills are needed in second game in order to get skills point for art gallery, and there are multiple inconsequential bugs in the third. None of these things stop normal gameplay, but can be very frustrating, if inexperienced or going for full game completion. There are also some minor issue with Steam achievements not always registering. I personally have 3 final goals, fully completed, that will not register. Again, not interfering with gameplay, just annoying. The camera while charging, or supercharging is wildly difficult to keep track of, making complex jumps over a void life-draining, though most of that is not necessary to complete the game. Best way to manage this last one is to have it set to active mode in game 2 and 3.

I 100% recommend this game, plus Youtube or Steam guides for anything you are stuck on. 4 1/2 stars out of 5 from me.

137549531.review:
Here's a tip I wished I knew after getting to the final world of Year of the Dragon: if you struggling to find a missing gem, especially in a world that has a bunch of mini-games or a off-path starring a certain kangaroo, press in the L stick and Sparx will point you where the gems are, including which portals they're in. I don't know if this works for the other two games, but they're also not Year of the Dragon where all the levels have 1 to 3 side quest portals with their own pile of gems!

Look I'm going to be honest with you: I bought this mostly for Spyro 1 and Ripto's Rage. I never really liked Year of the Dragon and the only way I 100% it as a kid was with help from my cousins. But with Reignited I decided to try and get all the achievements and do everything myself! And I did! And let me tell you Year of the Dragon is still my least favorite of the series. God I never want to 117% that thing again.

But I also think Year of the Dragon probably got the least amount of love out of the trilogy? Like I can't really say much about the minigames seeing as to how I needed help with the difficulty scaling with the original. Everything in Reignited's Year of the Dragon is on Normal Difficulty and a lot of the minigames and bosses have been tweaked, so it was all pretty easy for me to do this time. Except Bentley's boxing minigame because it didn't tell me I had a THIRD punch option.

But Year of the Dragon was so buggy! They all shared some technical bugs, but it just felt like everywhere I went I was seeing issue after issue! Sudden camera jump here, Spyro getting stuck in a corner there, Fairy trying to ask me about my camera for the 30th time just because I walked past her, enemies getting charged back suddenly zooming in close to the camera to do their death animations, Spyro not being able to charge through certain types of Enemies/Fodder animals because they were in their death animations (ok to be fair I also saw this a few times when doing the Flagkeeper Achievement in Scorch for Ripto's Rage), and oh my God the SKATEBOARDING. If you hit the edge or corner or something, you're either stuck or the game thinks you've hit a half-pipe and throws you up to let you do a few spins, but then you always end up breaking your board no matter how good you position your board afterwards and God help you if you're in the middle of a race or trying for the course record!

Like sure, some of those issues exist for the other games (not the NPCs or Skateboarding stuff) but they're way more tolerable. And even with the issues with Year of the Dragon, all the games are well remade: everything is placed almost exactly where they were supposed to be, they gave all the original dragons unique designs and animations (the baby dragons are... kinda like the original ones I guess?), certain characters like Moneybags will have different animation loops depending on what text they're currently saying, and Spyro has new designs for things like Superflame and Invincibility! Heck they even adjusted that annoying ledge to no longer be the hardest part of the Metalhead boss fight! But they also made Gulp a nightmare to round out all the nerfing they did so... have fun with Gulp.

You can still play Year of the Dragon, but you might find yourself more frustrated at times than enjoying it. The other two are great and I'll definitely be going back to them again in the future, but I'm not going to be hopping back into the third game anytime soon. Especially not to 117% it.

It's the Spyro games. They look amazing, play exactly the same, and neurons you haven't had activated in over a decade will ignite like an entire box of fireworks.

That said, there are a few problems that aren't going to get patched, so be warned:
- Playing above 30 FPS will occasionally stop you from progressing, breaking random parts of levels. It's easy to switch to 30 FPS and just work around it, but there's no excuse for not fixing it. If you're going to re-release a game, make it work properly.
- The camera, particularly in Spyro 2, could have used more attention. A few boss fights are made significantly harder than they need to be due to a camera that insists on focusing on what it wants rather than what you want.

Also, whoever decided that some of the "skill points" would be tied to perfect boss attempts... 136751623.review:
Never played the original games but I've been having fun with this, especially on the Steam Deck. Levels are colorful and vibrant and I enjoy exploring and finding ways to reach the areas that initially seem unreachable. Gameplay is pretty easy (except maybe the timed flying levels - I really hate those) and doesn't ever really punish you for "dying". The real challenge is in finding all of the dragons, eggs, and treasure in each level.

If you're looking for a game with story and challenging combat, this isn't really it, but it's a relaxing nostalgic collectathon. The visual upgrades look great and the game runs buttery smooth. One thing to note is that the physics are tied to framerate, so there are some bugs if you run above 120fps. 60fps or below is recommended to keep Spyro's full height jump, but the game is still "beatable" if you go above that. I noticed anything over 120 causes Spyro to continue "sliding", as if you have controller drift.

136751560.review:
Good stuff, but it has disruptive bugs. Basically there's seconds of input delay, and sometimes he'll continue moving in a direction after I've stopped, so Spyro gets himself killed a lot. You're not really getting much here that you don't get in the originals is another issue. There's now a map, and an optional updated control scheme, neither of which I use. As well as a new skill points system (the name is misleading, they're more like achievements internal to the game) borrowed from Ratchet & Clank. A little touch that's sadly absent, is that all games now use a brand new UI for the guidebook, one that's simplistic and uniform across all three games. The originals are not provided as alternative "classic" UIs (the music however, is, you can choose between originals and re-recordings from the pause menu). So for the nostalgia factor, there are some losses.

Overall, it hits the nostalgia, is worth it when on special, but ultimately I prefer the originals.

136543249.review:
I'll say this: I grew up playing these games, and these are some absolutely fantastic remakes!

The dragons have so much more character and uniqueness to them, the soundtrack is as bumpin' as ever, and the graphics have been vastly altered to appear more vibrant and polished. Nothing major has been altered or changed as far as I can tell, and so they seemed to have stayed nearly entirely true to the original. However, there are some minor alterations and, in particular, hiccups that are noticeably different from the original Spyro games. 

Spyro controls a bit less optimally than in the classic PS1 games. That is to say that it often feels like the camera is competing with you for control over Spyro, often causing you to miss a ledge you're gliding to, jump in the wrong direction entirely when attempting a glide, or miss a charge attack when you are trying to kill one or more enemies, resulting in you getting hit. This may not actually be a problem for anyone with no prior experience of Spyro. It may just be user error lol. 

One more bug I noticed, and this is only relevant for completionists, is that there are times when Sparx will absolutely not pick up a gem no matter how close you get to it, thus resulting in the occasional "missing gem" hunt. However, this issue is remedied by the ability to have Sparx point to any missing gems within a level. 

*Update* 
I ran into another bug during the Gulp encounter in Spyro 2 where the dinosaurs that drop items to attack Gulp with stopped carrying any items altogether, thus I had to exit the level and come back. 

Lastly, there were moments where the enemies really seemed to be struggling to move properly, thus rendering them mostly inert (in particular, the cannon shooters in Peace Keepers). On that same note, the egg thieves were made way easier to catch, often allowing you to torch them immediately upon reaching them. I hardly had to chase any of them. 

All in all, these remakes really capture and reignite the charm of the original series of games on the PS1. When on sale, I'd say it's definitely worth grabbing if you are a fan of somewhat simple collectathon platformers.

136289863.review:
A Nostalgic Flight Back to Childhood with Spyro The Dragon.

When it comes to feeling a wave of nostalgia wash over you, few games can rival the experience of diving back into the world of Spyro The Dragon. As my first game on the original PlayStation, Spyro holds a special place in my heart, and it remains a timeless classic that continues to enchant both newcomers and seasoned gamers alike.

From the moment the game loads and Spyro majestically swoops across the screen, it's hard not to be transported back to the simpler times of my youth. The vibrant colors, whimsical level design, and charming soundtrack evoke a sense of wonder and excitement that is rare to find in modern gaming.

Spyro The Dragon is one of the defining titles of the original PlayStation era. It tells the story of Spyro, a feisty little dragon on a quest to save his fellow dragons who have been turned into crystalline statues by the evil Gnasty Gnorc. Along the way, he must traverse multiple realms, defeat various foes, and collect gems and dragon eggs to restore peace to the Dragon Kingdom.

Replaying Spyro The Dragon is a joy, and it is evident that the game has aged gracefully. The controls remain responsive and intuitive, making it easy to guide Spyro through his adventure. The gameplay is simple yet engaging, with a mix of platforming, exploration, and combat that will keep you entertained for hours on end.

One of the highlights of revisiting Spyro The Dragon is the opportunity to rediscover the creative and diverse level design. Each realm is packed with unique challenges and hidden secrets, which, when combined with the vibrant colors and delightful soundtrack, make for an unforgettable gaming experience.

Of course, the nostalgic factor plays a significant role in the enjoyment of this title. For many of us who grew up with the original PlayStation, Spyro The Dragon was our introduction to the world of 3D platformers. As such, the game represents a simpler time in gaming, before online multiplayer, microtransactions, and endless sequels took center stage.

In conclusion, Spyro The Dragon remains a remarkable gaming experience that has stood the test of time. Whether it's your first time exploring the Dragon Kingdom or you're revisiting it for a nostalgic trip down memory lane, Spyro offers a delightful, captivating, and enchanting journey that is sure to leave a lasting impression. So, dust off that old PlayStation, put on your rose-tinted glasses, and let yourself be whisked away to a world of magical realms, colorful characters, and unforgettable adventures with our beloved little dragon.

136157515.review:
I used to speed run the first game on PS1 like every weekend when I was younger. It's probably my all time favorite game. 

I REALLY love that they remade these. The remastered graphics are gorgeous, but if you're coming straight from the original PS1 to this, it will be jarring. I actually embarrassed myself in front of my boyfriend and his brother my first run through: I was so used to how forgiving the polygons of the PS1 were for just constant charging everywhere, I ran into almost everything in this one. I also liked that they really characterized each dragon and individualized them more. 

There is an option to have the original game's soundtracks playing instead of the new music: Needless to say, I don't even know what the remastered music sounds like because the OG music is amazing. 

Besides all that, the storylines are the same, the maps are identical, as is all the placements of chests and gems. My only real gripe: In the PS1 version, if you couldn't find that ONE red gem you needed to complete a level, you could just stand still and wait for the sparkle to show you wherever it was in the distance. I don't believe that little exploit is in these ones. The hound gnorcs in Toasty's level are also WAY more aggressive: A lot of the mobs are actually a lot quicker.

Here's to hoping maybe they do Sly Cooper next! (I know it's not the same company but I can dream).

136121161.review:
This review was copy pasted from a message I sent to my friends. There might be weird phrasing since it was not originally meant to be a Steam review tied to the game's page.

Besides the OG Skylanders and playing 10 minutes of a random Spyro game on a PS2 in PLACE as a kid after school then getting bored, this is my first time experiencing Spyro!

This trilogy is absolutely amazing! It is a must play that everyone should get to experience. 3 really good games (2 which are amazing) that are an absolute joy to play. About 30 hours of content all together (my fully completed save says 25 hours and Steam says 40 hours). Must buy!

I 120% (fully completed) the game as well as platinum-ing the achievements for it and thoroughly enjoyed the whole experience! The game is NOT hard at all, with me casually 100%ing each level as I went, just making sure I got everything before I moved to the next area. But I think that is what made it so fun; for a game to be a super chill collectathon that doesn't have you searching every pixel for hours so you can find one chest behind a wall. The game was also pretty short. I beat the game in less than 7 hours. The art is amazing, Spyro feels great to control (though I would switch the flame and charge buttons if I could), the music is fun, the characters are great and make you chuckle, and the story is kiddy so very easy to sit back and just have a good time with.

If you are looking for challenge in a 3D platformer/collectathon, this is not it. But if you want a fun, chill experience to kick back with, this game will be the PERFECT tool to scratch that itch with!

I cannot wait to jump back into the Reignited Trilogy so I can play the other 2 games, and if they capture the same whimsical, fun, chill feeling that the first game created, I will have so much fun with them as well :D

Edit:
Just finished Spyro: Ripto's Rage! This is the second game in the Reignited Trilogy.

I 100% (fully completed) the game as well as platinum-ing the achievements for it and really liked the game! Spyro 2 does some things better than Spyro 1 and some things worse than it. To me, the things it did worse are bigger cons than the pros you got from the things it did better. Still a good game that is immensely fun to play and something I think everyone should get to play someday! Just not as good as Spyro 1. Spyro 2 is less flowy and focuses more on challenges and characters. You are stopped multiple times throughout every level to talk to someone to either help them, for them to give you something, or for some other reason. While I do think the challenges are fun and a good mixup from the general gameplay loop, the greatness of Spyro is getting to run around as that little purple dragon, so any time that you cannot do that is time wasted in the game. I should add that this game is a hair longer than the first. While I beat Spyro 1 in a little under 7 hours, I beat Spyro 2 in a little under 8 hours. Both are still shorter than an average AAA game, but I think it is interesting to see the little change in playtime.

Spyro 2 has real boss fights! Since there is a more understandable and concrete story in Spyro 2 ((this is not a spoiler) Ripto has screwed everything up so you have to help the people of every world you visit), there are enemies which you definitely want to fight/kill, and to see that those enemies have actual fights around them and not just fall over like a cardboard cutout in the wind, it is very nice. Now, I am not necessarily a boss fight lover in a game like this. I kinda liked that Spyro 1's boss fights were just excuses to put another level in the game. But for the person who is looking for this sort of experience, you can find it in Spyro 2.

Spyro 2 also is more difficult than everything being breeze through easy. I would not say that Spyro 2 is hard at all, but it is no longer (what some may call (not me)) brain numbingly easy. The puzzles of Spyro 2 are definitely more fun, engaging, and complicated, which is a very nice addition to the games as a whole. One thing I did not like about Spyro 2's added difficulty is how they tinkered with the gem placement in the levels. I think Spyro 1 had the perfect feeling of no gem being super annoying to find so you wanted to find all before you ended a level. In Spyro 2, though this happened fairly rarely, there were times that I needed to use Sparx to guide me to the missing gems and they were hidden in frankly stupid spots and unfun to search every crack of the level to find.

Overall, Spyro 2 is a very good game that everyone should play; it adds somewhat real story elements to an otherwise story-less game and offers more reason/incentive to keep progressing, but messes with the gameplay loop and screws up the flow of the game so that it is no longer as perfectly tuned as Spyro 1 (Spyro 2 still has an impeccably made gameplay loop, but its flaws are apparent when held up to its older brother).

I am super excited to get into the last game of the trilogy when I can. The visuals of both of the games I have played so far have been stunning and if the third game keeps up with the first 2 in gameplay, then I am in for another treat!

Edit 2: Just finished Spyro: Year of the Dragon (Game 3)! This was the final game in the Spyro Reignited Trilogy (2018).

I absolutely loved this game! I 117% it in less than 10 hours! What Spyro 2 lost in trying to make every level have some sort of story (and thereby giving unnecessary and annoying cutscenes), Spyro 3 trimmed down on. What Spyro 2 lost in trying to make every level have a weird gimic that didn't work much of the time, Spyro 3 fixed by keeping the absolutely amazing gameplay loop and only adding gimics around the edges of the levels. Spyro 3 was a great game that is a must play if you enjoyed Spyro 1.

While I still prefer Spyro 1's way of putting the barest of reasons in the player's head so they can go about playing the elite level design and gameplay, Spyro 3 did put a story in the game that has more to care about.

The collectibles in Spyro 3 are back to greatness! Spyro 1 felt amazing with everything you collected. Spyro 2 made the main collectible (besides gems) these weird special gems which did not feel nearly as nice to collect as other items. Spyro 3 made dragon eggs the main collectible (besides gems), which felt great because it made you feel like you were saving the dragon species by beating the game. Also, Spyro 2 had this horrible idea of taking gems out of enemies when you kill them, so you never had any incentive to kill enemies besides when they put an arbitrary lock on the next area until you kill enough things. Spyro 3 brought back gems when you kill enemies (gems feel awesome to get) so you really wanted to defeat everything in a stage and collect those juicy gems!

I must admit, the skateboard levels were not my cup of tea. It was annoying to first learn the controls, and when I did become somewhat comfortable, there was a lot of poor collision and registering of tricks. The gimic characters were fun in my opinion and they did not overstay their welcome. They were not more fun than controlling Spyro, and I think the devs knew that, so they gave you one full level with them, then 2-4 sublevels to let you experience them but not make the game about them.

I thoroughly loved Spyro 3 and had a great time with it! I hope all who like 3D platformers/collectathons get to experience this "gem" of a game!

135904799.review:
Spyro Reignited Trilogy is like the ultimate nostalgia trip for anyone who grew up playing Spyro on their PlayStation 1 (or anyone who just really loves dragons).

The game's graphics are stunning, with colorful, vibrant worlds that'll make you feel like you're flying through a technicolor dream. It's like playing a Lisa Frank coloring book, but with way more fire-breathing action.

The gameplay is just as fun as you remember it, with Spyro's signature gliding, flame-breathing, and treasure-collecting all intact. It's like revisiting an old friend, but with better graphics and less awkward conversations.

And let's not forget about Spyro himself. He's just as cute and spunky as you remember him, with his sassy attitude and dragon-sized ego. It's like playing as the lovechild of Puff the Magic Dragon and Deadpool.

The only downside to the game is that it can be a bit too easy at times. I mean, when you're a fire-breathing dragon, it's kind of hard to have any real challenges. It's like playing a game of tag, but you're always "it" because you can breathe fire.

But overall, Spyro Reignited Trilogy is a blast from the past that's sure to please any Spyro fan (or dragon lover). So grab your controller, take a deep breath, and get ready to reignite your love for this spunky little dragon.

135035591.review:
This game is worth getting, but I'd wait for a sale. I've been really enjoying playing through all three games as I only remembered the original from my childhood. Its a great relaxing mix of platformer and exploration. I love the fact that you can do the level in any order you decide and that the hub worlds are levels in and of themselves. 

That said, its worth noting that the first game in the trilogy is by far the strongest. The second game is still good but there is a noticeable shift in tone and its clear the creators were trying to figure out what to do to define Spyro as a franchise. Its still fun and a good game but it also has quite a few minigames with completely different tones. That said, its got the same relaxed and fun feel to it. Though, having to pay to unlock skills like being able to climb a latter is frustrating when the skills are needed in levels long before you unlock them! I'm not a huge fan of being forced to do a level multiple times because I didn't have the skill unlocked the first time. It does however add more skills to the game which really opens up what Spyro can do. 

The third game, Year of the Dragon, is a mess. Moneybags is back and once again forcing you to pay to be able to continue the level/free a character. I like finding all the gems in a level so its never been an issue of having enough but its still frustrating. More importantly, this third entry doesn't know what it wants to be. You have to free other characters - and then you play as them. That would be fine but they all have different skills/abilities and there are a five of them:  Kangaroo, Monkey, Yeti, Dragonfly and Penguin! I just want to play as Spyro! Add in the fact that they have mini levels inside levels that force you to use these characters and some are very very different turning game play into a side scrawler or first person shooter and its just a weird tone shift. There is also the fact that the mini games have made a return and suddenly you're playing a skateboarding game all about tricks/skills and racing. That said, you can focus on the main game and the plot is fun. The third game feels easier than the first two, especially in terms of bosses.

The levels all shows completion percentage and you can teleport yourself into any level you've been in before to go back and try to 100% it. All three games have a special area or level you can access only if you 100% the game so if you're a completionist it will reward you for it. Overall, highly worth getting if you want a fun, relaxing game.

135006489.review:
Spyro Reignited Trilogy is a remake of what are clearly some of the best games that the 3d collectathon platformer genre has to offer. Spyro's glide move allow the level designers to use vertical space in an interesting way. Levels are also small enough to make 100%ing level collectibles not feel like a complete chore.

The first game can feel basic at times while the later games introduce diversions that are often not as strong as the core platforming gameplay. but each of the three games is very good.

Note that there are a couple of places where framerate causes problems for the game logic. If something in the game seems harder than it should, or you get stuck in progressing through a level, you might want to try dropping the framerate to 30fps to see if that resolves the issue.

[b]Spyro Reignited Trilogy[/b] is an excellent remaster of the [b]original PlayStation 1 Spyro games[/b].

It’s a 3D [b]platformer/collectathon[/b] where you play as [b]Spyro[/b], a young dragon who must [b]save his world from various threats[/b]. You will [b]explore different realms[/b], [b]collect gems[/b], and fight against some [b]peculiar bosses[/b].

While [b]the game is not very long or hard[/b], it offers a lot of fun and charm. However, [b]the controls and hitboxes can sometimes be frustratingly unfair[/b].

This remaster [b]has amazing graphics that make everything look vibrant and detailed[/b]. The levels are [b]diverse and creative[/b], ranging from medieval castles to futuristic cities. [b]The music and sound effects[/b] are also great and [b]match the atmosphere of each world[/b].

One of the [b]best features[/b] of this trilogy is the[b] ability to use Sparx to point where the gems are located[/b]. I [b]strongly recommend[/b] using this feature to [u]not miss a single gem[/u]: 

[table]
[tr]
	[th]Device[/th]
	[th]Button[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]Keyboard[/td]
	[td][b]P[/b][/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]Controller[/td]
	[td][b]L3[/b] [i](press the left analog stick)[/i][/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

The games, however, do have some [b]annoying bugs related to the FPS cap[/b]. To fix this, I recommend setting your FPS cap to 120, although [b]it may be different for you depending on your device and preferences[/b]:
[list]

[*] [b]In Spyro 3[/b], the achievement [b]"Man the Cannons, Man"[/b] [u]may be bugged[/u] in the [b]Lost Fleet[/b] level, you will need [u]to restart the game and kill all the vultures again to unlock it[/u] (if you are lucky).

Graphics are pretty good. I don't think the remaster changed how Spyro played very much. I definitely get the nice, happy, nostalgic feeling from playing. hmm, yes very cozy.

Now, overall I wouldn't recommend this remastered game though (I will however definitely recommend the original on the console). Best I can describe the movement is that it's slippery. It constantly feels like I'm playing on butter. This really sucks because several times, it's led to my demise, usually in the form of falling off a cliff. Sort of related to this complaint is that the controls feel kind of unresponsive. Perhaps other people may disagree with me on this, but it just doesn't feel snappy enough for me to enjoy playing. 

I hate to say this, but this might be the worst remaster I've ever played. But despite all of the negatives, overall I'd say this an ok game. Not great, not terrible (as I've seen worse), just ok. So I don't regret playing this, I just wish it was polished up a little more.

Edit: After a little more time with this, I have to say that the controls ended up being worse than I thought. A few scenarios in this game ended becoming a lot more frustrating for the wrong reasons.

134798499.review:
I cannot begin to even put it into words, that is the effect this game had on me. Not only was Spyro my childhood, as for many other players, but it was also always a very well-constructed game.  I would say it if a good fit for all ages, parents and children alike. The gameplay is relaxing, sometimes a little challenging, the worlds are vast and full of secrets, and the whole atmosphere is amazing. This pack includes a remaster of 3 different games, so there are dozens of hours of content even without replaying any level in any of the games. The semi-open world was ahead of its time and still keeps up to this day. You can choose which world/level you want to go to (with small limitations like areas accessible only after completing certain objectives), so the order in which you play them is largely up to you.

I could give a different opinion on each of the games, but they would all be praising the games, both the originals and the remakes, for doing such a good job. Needless to say, stepping into those worlds again after about 20 years gave me a memorgasmic feeling, and that is the only way I can describe it. Everything felt the same and yet so new. It made me feel old, but in a good, melancholic way, seeing the game grow up along with us like this puts things in a new perspective. I relive my childhood through this game, as well as make new memories with it now.

I never thought a game could impress me so much. I never thought I'd be able to feel Spyro again, almost through the eyes of a child like I used to, and yet I did. Although the originals didn't have flashy features and amazing graphics, back then I think we all saw those games like the remakes are now, it's incredible what imagination can do. The games are true to the original, while bringing so many improvements. If you've played Spyro before, you are going to absolutely love this game, and if you haven't, you're in for a huge treat.

134569739.review:
[h1] [i] For every good battle, you need a good adversary. [/i] [/h1]

A lot of reviewers are nostalgic gamers who played the game in the early 2000s and I was no exception. [i] Spyro [/i] is a beautiful game about a purple dragon who saves the world from evil monsters - sometimes the monster turns dragons into crystal, at other times it wants to rule the world of Avalar, and at other times it yearns for longevity, but for this it is necessary to steal dragon eggs.

Reignited Trilogy is a trilogy of Spyro games by Insomniac Games [i] (you might know Ratchet & Clank or Marvel's Spiderman) [/i], remastered by Toys for Bob [i] (I think the most interesting thing here is that they made Skylanders, which is the final part of Spyro's story) [/i]. We know that the games in between (eg Enter the Dragonfly) were terrible, so everyone was afraid of a remaster of the original trilogy, which was the biggest success at the time. I think the remaster was very successful, but I have to admit that there are more bugs and glitches (in gliding and landing, camera orientation, egg cutscene, etc.) that sometimes got on my nerves. But the nostalgia is too strong and I rate the game very positively.

[b] My Favorite Quote [/b]
[i] Hunter: You're a dragon? [/i]
[i] Spyro: You got a problem with that, pussycat? [/i]

[b] My Favorite Achievement [/b]
[i] 8000 Reasons to Kick Butt [/i]

[b] My Favorite Skill Point [/b]
[i] Peacekeepers: Scare 6 Gnorcs into tents [/i]

Ratings:
Game Presentation: 5/5
Narrative: 5/5
Gameplay: 4/5
Graphics: 5/5
Audio: 5/5
Price: 5/5

134558713.review: The physics are tied to the framerate, so the further you go above 30fps, the more the game bugs out, with some bugs appearing on as few as 60fps. I can forgive the lack of proper mouse and keyboard support, seeing as these games are meant to be played with a controller, but even the controller support is bad. Despite there being an option to invert the Y axis in the camera settings, it remains inverted on the flying levels no matter what you set this option to. Full rebinding of controls is also not supported, with the game instead giving you two different control schemes to choose from. I found that while I had no difficulty controlling Spyro using either scheme, trying to move around as the bird guy was a pain in the ass. From a technical perspective, this port is objectively trash. The games are decently fun (though I would argue that they're really nothing special by today's standards), just be sure to have a bottle of ibuprofen nearby for the inevitable headache you will get from the low framerate if you plan on playing it. Alternatively, have fun dealing with the buggy physics, softlocks, and impossible jumps that come with playing at a high framerate. You would think that game developers would be able to figure this out after 21 years.

133521973.review:
Spyro Reignited Trilogy is an absolutely fantastic remaster of the classic Spyro the Dragon series. The game includes remastered versions of the first three Spyro games, complete with updated graphics, improved controls, and all of the charm and humor that made the original games so great.

The graphics in Spyro Reignited Trilogy are simply stunning. Every level is packed with detail and color, and the updated character designs and animations make Spyro and his friends look better than ever. The game also includes some fantastic new features, such as the ability to play as Spyro's friends in certain levels, which adds even more variety to the gameplay.

The gameplay in Spyro Reignited Trilogy is just as fun and engaging as it was in the original games. The controls have been updated to feel more responsive and fluid, and the game includes a number of quality of life improvements that make it easier and more enjoyable to play. The game strikes a great balance between challenging and accessible, making it perfect for both new players and fans of the original games.

The only real downside to Spyro Reignited Trilogy is that it doesn't include any new content beyond the original three games. While the updated graphics and gameplay are certainly worth revisiting these classic games for, there isn't much here for players who have already played the originals to completion.

Overall, Spyro Reignited Trilogy is a fantastic remaster of a classic game series. It's perfect for fans of the original games, as well as anyone who loves platformers and wants to experience some classic gaming goodness. Highly recommended!

133181205.review:
Pains me to say this, but what we have here is the clear example of a "mix bag" and playing it you can understand why Spyro didn´t lasted as a mascot platformer as much as others from the same time. Giving it a bad review would be harsh, but giving it a possitive one fills a little dishonest, and I´ve done both as my review for the title keept changing as I played along. If Steam had at third option in the middle probably would the one I would choose for this.

 Spyro 1 is the real treasure is and with better visuals and camera control it´s more comfortable to play now than ever. 2 and 3 I feel they went overboard with mini-games and locked areas, a collectathon is fine, but a collectathon+metrovenian can become frustrating, particularly when axis-Y controllers can´t be changed for the controler. In general the game´s option do seem to have come directly from the late 90s, way to little options. The camera controls in all games are an improvement (except in some areas with fixxed cameras where it´s wonky at best), but other than that and visual stuff, most of the game it´s just the same, no particular extras. Some mini games in 2 and 3 have become easier, and others harder, but overall tons are very annoying. 

Overall it´s a good game, mostly because the old ones where good, not as good as some other platformers and with some misguided ideas, but still solid and pretty nostalgic. If you have the patience for it you can 100% the game quite easily and get 40-60 hours for a game that on sale can reach 10 euros, not a bad deal if you like the genre, which doesn´t have that many games this days that aren´t just remakes or not very well put together indie stuff.

133141085.review:
No other 3D platformer can try to compete with Spyro.

For those who haven't played Spyro before, let me break down each game for you;


So you've got Spyro 1, the OG of the OG. Gnasty Gnorc (the G's are NOT silent*) is upset because the news downplayed how cool he is and now he's on a rampage. Gameplay & mechanically, I'd call this game pretty average by today's standards.
You've got some very tight platforming, two different attacks (charge & flame breath), a variety of 29 unique levels, and a -lot- of things to collect -- Gems, dragons, & eggs all scattered throughout the world.

The levels?? They're fantastic. They all have their own personality & varying complexities. Some of them make you think (*cough* Tree Tops), others make you race, and some you just want to explore. 

Completing the game is quite simple and doesn't require too much involvement, however, the real fun is in getting 100% completion for that fun final stage. 

By today's standards, there are some faults -- The boss fights aren't very unique or interesting & there isn't too much variety in the gameplay loop, but it's still a fantastic time.

*The G's are actually silent

----

Then you've got Spyro 2: Ripto's Rage. The developers looked at Spyro 1 and thought "What can we do to make this better?" 

The boss fights are better, the levels are better, they added more variety and engagement to the gameplay loop, they added little 'missions' & fun challenges within the stages to complete. 

They've added swimming & climbing, and timed flights. They've added new attacks, and abilities, and so many new collectibles. They've also added some friends (like a cheetah!) and one particularly greedy NPC to spend your gems on. 

Everything about this game feels polished & praise-worthy. Above average by today's standards.

---

Then we've got Spyro: Year of the Dragon... This is where the devs go wild.

They all gather in a musty old board room around a big wooden table and someone says "Spyro 2 was too good... How can we possibly make it any better?!"

And a year later... They do it... They actually make the game better...

"How?" you ask....

THEY GIVE THE CHEETAH A SKATEBOARD. WATCH ME DO A BACKFLIP DAD!!

12/10. If you're a fan of 3D platformers it's a must play in my books.

132952986.review:
God, this was an absolute trip down memory lane :') The Spyro trilogy was the first set of games I played as a 6 year old in roughly 2003, and at that time we didn't have a 128kb memory card for my PS1, so every time I'd shut off my console I'd have to start from square one again. 

I like to think that if 6 year old me knew that 19 years later, I had gone back and completed the Spyro trilogy in it's full as a 25 year old adult, he'd be pretty dang stoked. Especially knowing that after all these years I've finally gotten my well deserved, and long awaited revenge on Mr. Moneybags.

Replaying these games gave me an incomparable and indescribable flood of nostalgia that was definitely complimented by the modern graphics of the remastered version. The graphics made the game feel inviting and not so outdated, they were improved and different, but definitely not unrecognizable. There's also an 'enhanced' soundtrack, which was close enough to the original that I still remembered the sounds and notes from most of them which was a real treat.

If there was one thing I wish the game featured, it would be the option to toggle the graphics from the old models and newer ones. There were many points where I wish I could've been interacting with the old models of Hunter and Elora specifically, mostly during the skateboarding events, because those are what I was looking forward to and what stuck with me the most from when I was a kiddo.

Thank you for this lovely revival of one of my favorite childhood games. <3

Please bring back Ape Escape ;)

132800555.review:
Tras haber terminado Spyro Reignited Trilogy al 100% con todos los logros publico mi reseña.
 Para empezar hay qué destacar qué este juego es un "remake" de los tres Spyros de PS1.
¿Qué incluye el juego?
 El juego incluye los tres Spyros de PS1 (a un precio bastante económico) hechos desde cero.
¿Por qué debería jugar/probar este juego?  
 Si no has jugado a los Spyros de PS1 o quieres "rejugarlos", esta es la mejor forma de hacerlo.

Puntos a favor.
- Gráficos hermosos.
- Banda sonora espectacular.
- Voces y sonidos grandiosos.
- Existe una linea de dificultad entre pasarte el juego sin agarrar nada e intentar pasártelo al 100%.
- El propio juego te anima a qué lo completes al 100% dándote recompensas (como el portal a la costa del dragón en Spyro 2)
- Varias opciones de personalización tales como habilitar el mapa, cambiar a la música del juego original, etc...
- Los logros, estos te presentan minidesafios qué pasaran desde vencer a un jefe sin qué te maten a intentar volar por 5 segundos.

 Puntos intermedios.
- Sí bien las mecánicas están pulidas en ciertas ocasiones estas son muy difíciles de utilizar llegando a ser muy frustrante.
- En cierto punto los niveles se pueden volver repetitivos y pueden llegar a aburrirte.
- En el caso de Spyro 3, los compañeros tienen mecánicas o ángulos de cámaras muy incómodos.
- Puedes omitir toda la historia y dará completamente igual.

 Puntos en contra.
- Existen ciertos bugs qué son muy molestos.
- Ciertos minijuegos qué resultan muy frustrantes.
Edit: Algunas voces no coordinan con como se expresa cierto personaje
 
En conclusión, ¿recomiendo este juego?
Claro qué sí es un juego muy divertido (aún qué a veces sea demasiado frustrante) y de verdad qué los gráficos son hermosos.
Si te sobra pasta y tienes un ordenador lo suficientemente potente te recomiendo qué lo compres o al menos lo pruebes.

(Recomendaciones mías a la hora de jugar)
- Si te lo puedes permitir juega con los gráficos al máximo.
- Saca muchísimas fotos, a veces pueden quedar cosas muy lindas.
- Utiliza la música, esta complementa los niveles.
- Tomate tú tiempo para jugar a los tres juegos, no solo intentes pasarlo rápido, intenta apreciar los paisajes y escuchar la música.
- Pasatelo al 100%, de verdad qué es satisfactorio tener todo el contenido del juego.
Nota final: 9,5/10

132127228.review:
After playing this on and off for the last two years or so, slowly working my way through it, I finally finished the Spyro Reignited trilogy today! Link to my Youtube playthrough below, if anyone wants to see a sample of gameplay before buying:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slRLzjjM7eg&list=PL05Yc3_TEBpPZgy9X7NtRtpypMDYher6i

But now, on to the review: this is a remaster of the first three Spyro games. I loved 3D platformers when I was a kid, but sadly I never got to play the original Spyro games back in the day. Fortunately, thanks to this remaster I've been able to see what I missed out on. The devs have done a tremendous job of remastering the originals. The visuals are stunning, the gameplay is smooth, and the characters are all charming and eccentric.

The Reignited trilogy is also a very family-friendly set of games, ideal for kids or older players alike; there's something for everyone. In terms of gameplay, it's very much what you'd expect a 3D platformer to be - and truth be told, the style of gameplay is quite consistent across all three of the remastered titles, so it can get a bit repetitive after a while. But the games do try to throw in different mechanics from time to time, just to vary things up a little - such as levels where you switch to different characters with slightly different mechanics, or pilot vehicles such as boats, submarines, hovercraft, skateboards, and more.

Altogether, it's a recommendation from me!

131525461.review:
Spyro Reignited Trilogy es un rework de la saga de juegos para PS1, dicho esto, si eres de los que como en mi caso el Spyro fue uno de tus primeros juegos de PS1 y rejugarlo con gráficos nuevos supone recordar uno de esos juegos que tantas horas (y algún quebradero de cabeza) te dio en tu juventud pues seguramente te lo pases como un enano, si por el contrario no has jugado nunca y esta puede ser tu primera vez aún así lo recomiendo pero con más contras que pros.
He leído muchas reviews, post y comentarios que hablan de los fallos y bugs del juego, yo sinceramente no he tenido crasheos en el juego ni bugs realmente importantes excepto por unas cosillas.

1º Yo juego con teclado y ratón y en este apartado sí me he encontrado algunos fallos. Mi recomendación sería no tocar los controles, aprende a jugar con los que trae el juego de base y no los cambies, yo cambié dos teclas y ya fue suficiente para tener algún problema. Durante el Spyro 1 y el 2 todo fue bien, pero en el 3 hay unos niveles de Skate con turbo y el turbo no funcionaba pese a estar vinculado a una tecla que fuera de ese nivel si funcionaba, la única solución que encontré fue darle a restablecer los controles por defecto, hacer el nivel y al salir volver a ponerlos a mi gusto. 

2º La gran mayoría de los jefes son una chorrada, pero si te gusta hacer logros como a mí posiblemente pases un mal trago en el Spyro 2. Parece ser que a los Boses les han tocado la puntería y la inteligencia de los proyectiles ''guiados'' y algunos logros piden que completes el boss sin recibir daño así que sin hacer spoilers os recomiendo no daros de cabezazos y simplemente completar el juego, ya que en todos los Spyros puedes rehacer los combates y niveles y en concreto en el Spyro 2 completar el juego os dará una gran ayuda para este tipo de logros.

3º Los Fp's. Es posible que en algunos niveles veáis bugs o un comportamiento errático en algún enemigo o mecánica del juego, os recomiendo que si por ejemplo, un enemigo no hace X cosa y no podéis continuar el nivel o hay un salto que estáis 100% seguros que se hace de una manera y aún haciéndolo perfecto no llegáis por muy poco, posiblemente la solución la encontraréis bajando los Fp's a 30. Lamentablemente este juego es un port de consolas a PC y por ello el juego está programado para funcionar a 30 fp's y al ponerlo a más pues es posible que el juego se rompa por algún lado. A mí solo me ha pasado 2 veces en los tres juegos pero es posible que existan mas fallos que se solucionen de esta manera. 

Por todo lo demás, esta recomendación la escribo después de haberme sacado todos los logros tanto del propio juego como los de Steam así que puedo decir con conocimiento de causa que me ha gustado esta resurrección de una parte de mi infancia, diría que es un 98% o 99% idéntico al original lo cual me parece perfecto personalmente. 

Espero que lo disfruteis!

131139261.review:
This remake is overflowing with detail, but unfortunately the game is plagued by technical issues stemming from a lazy port. FoV is locked and is way too low by default for a widescreen computer monitor. There are many bugs at high frame rates (above 50) that can make the game unplayable. In my case, setting the game to unlimited in the menu and adding an FPS limit of 120 on the Nvidia control panel seemed to fix the sliding and the softlock on Alpine Ridge, but results may vary. It's also failing to keep my cursor in my main monitor, forcing me to disable my second monitor if I want to play. The mismatch between vertical and horizontal mouse sensitivity when looking around can only be fixed through config files, but doing so merely shifts the problem to flying and swimming controls instead.

Another weird thing to note is that the game asks for a firewall exception which it doesn't need and causes a Steam process to access your microphone whenever it's running. There's a problem with loading times in the first game too, making them much slower than they need to be.

You can find some fixes and workarounds on PCGaminiki, but you shouldn't need to do all this shit just to play a game properly. It's been years since release and these glaring issues are still there, so the game is pretty abandoned by the studio.
https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Spyro_Reignited_Trilogy

130865677.review:
This is a tough review to write, but with all the common, repeatable bugs that hinder progress on the PC version, I can't recommend this game. It pains me to say it, but maybe get this on another platform if you don't mind the 30 FPS cap. Toys for Bob (or, most likely, Activision) did not and will not bother to fix what is most likely easy bug fixes tied to framerate and that's a shame. 

As for the games, I think they're fine. The only nostalgia I have for these games is maybe the Second game (I vaguely remember the hockey game) and the opening area of the first game since it was a demo in Crash Warped. So really, these are relatively fresh on my gaming palette, and after it's all said and done, these games are a test of patience to complete. 

As collectathons, each game has their own unique frustration: The first game has horrible gliding controls that make you commit or die; the second game has some real D-tier levels and trash boss fights; and the third game makes completion spotty with locked characters and a lazy distribution of gems. 

I ended up completing Spyro 1 and 2 relatively easily, but once I got to the third game the seams were beginning to break and by the fourth hub world I was ready to be done. I didn't hate this experience--and in fact, booting it up is a joy and the games look and sound wonderful, Toys for Bob is a great developer--but between the myriad of negative points and the poor, permanently buggy PC port that it is, I cannot recommend it unless you're hankering for nostalgia or just really don't care about the issues and can play around them.

TL;DR - Spyro the Dragon: 7/10; Ripto's Rage: 7.5/10; Year of the Dragon: 6/10. The game looks and runs beautifully, except for critical buggy areas that are replicated 99% of the time and for all players. Glitches, game-breaking framerate-related issues, frustrating moments with a few very high points. Do not recommend the PC version, unfortunately.

130804171.review: These games were my favorite growing up, I played them endlessly for decades. These remakes are for the most part extremely faithful to the original games, and I gained immense joy from seeing my childhood hero remade for the modern day. Much of my enjoyment does definitely come out of nostalgia, but I do think that this is a good game and that the devs have done well walking the fine line of remaking an old game.

130795207.review:
Despite a many visual improvements, there's also tons of more bugs added, especially in the 2nd and 3rd games. Spyro 3 gets it the worst, with some mini games not functioning at all, skate board physics completely busted, and a myriad of small glitches that can add up to a frustrating experience.  

I think the sound design is butchered. A lot of the sound effects lack impact both compared to the original and in a vacuum. Things like gem sounds, sparx sounds, menu sounds, enemy sounds, crystal dragon sounds and so on are so lame and quiet they might as well not even be there. Voice acting is spotty, with some performances being grate to some being really generic.

As for my last point, I think the UI is a major downgrade from the original. Things like Dragon Counter, guidebook, talismans ,fonts, and icons are polished to the point of being soulless. A similar comparison would be the visual change from Borderlands 2 to 3 where all the menus became more "techy" and thus losing the charm of the cartoony health bars. I think the main thing I miss this the fact that the guidebook pages literally flipped in the original with 3D talismans and page flaps. Now we just have a really empty menu of lists, in which half of it goes unused.

To conclude, these are my main grievances. The glitches alone make it an unfun experience, but the fact that this remake was a little "too faithful" to the point where there's nothing new to warrant playing this over the originals.

130441010.review:
Spyro the dragon's series has a special place in my heart, from playing on the original 3 games on the PS1 when I was a kid until the Skylanders games I have played pretty much every title to come out.

There has been ups and downs with Spyro as a whole but when the reignited trilogy came out I was super happy to see Spyro return, upon completing the games and doing this review I am 100% happy with the results, I can't wait for a new Spyro title!

---------------------------------
           GAME REVIEW
---------------------------------

10/10 for graphics, the style works super well with Spyro and I have the official art of Spyro book which I have read through a few times and I enjoyed every part of it. 

9/10 engine, the game runs really well on my main pc rig but the steam deck doesn't like it as much, I understand that it is not as powerful but the engine has been notorious for having *some* performance issues, though overall it works really well

10/10 gameplay remastered, this game is EXACTLY like how the original games ran and played, included many many quality of life additions such as the map and keeping consistent in abilities, adding on I like the skills, as I like to push my skills further.

There however was a few bugs I found, an example is clipping and getting stuck on doors in some of the worlds, though this was not game stopping and I free'd myself a lot of the time. I also did notice that ripto's staff clips through his clothing in his arena cut-scene.

Overall I enjoyed this and want the team to strive for bigger things, I hope to one day also help with something in the Spyro universe. Thank you developers at games for bob for remaking the first 3 games.

PS: you should also have added the regional titles for Spyro 2 as here it's called "Gateway to Glimmer" and not "Ripto's Rage".

129343932.review:
Spyro 1 - Better than people give it credit. It's not even fair to compare it to Crash 1 in the same sense of "oh it's more simple". It's actually the simplicity that works really well here, unlike with Crash 1 where the levels are dumb too. Anyway, the remaster does a fantastic job remaking the old dragons and giving them actual character rather than "recolor 15" of the old days.

Spyro 2 - Hot take, it's worse than 1! But not a bad one. It's not a "step up" in the same way Crash 2 is at all. It's more like a step up in an experimental way. When Spyro became a bit more complex. Certainly not bad, but has a lot more things holding it back than 1.

Spyro 3 - Pretty solid overall. This is where the experimentation in 2 goes to find a proper game. Improved controls for new characters are also a plus in this remaster. In my opinion anyway. Very good and my second favorite of the three.

All three are very worth the playthrough or five. Despite the music being so-so. It's fitting for the stages, but it's not really as memorable as Crash. But the rest makes up for it I'd say. Love these!

129114182.review:
Pluses:
Faithful recreation of the original games. That includes dialogue, level design, and not adding features the games did not have from releasing chronologically. An example of that would be the hover from 2, not being in 1.
Even though the graphics and visuals are beautiful, I don't feel like they take away from the game's faithful recreation of simplistic level design.
I will give this plus to Proton/Steam, but the game runs as expected on Linux.

Negatives:
The game was hard coded for consoles, so the PC port has slight issues.
Dual Sense support functions, as long as you set it up through both Steam and the game. Launching the game outside of Steam is a no go if you want to use a Dual Sense, and likely all PlayStation controllers.
Game cannot run above 100-120 fps without Spyro having a bug where when he is stationary, walking, or charging, he will slowly slide along the ground in a random direction. Even on monitors with Vsync turned on with native refresh rates above 100-120, the sliding bug will still happen.
Game is hard coded to not display above 16:9 aspect ratio, even though wider aspect ratios are options in the game. There are 3rd party fixes for this on Windows, but not for Linux/SteamOS.

128379192.review:
I grew up with these games. I played the original trilogy annually until this came out when I immediately purchased it for the PS4 and recently bought it here as well. Overall, this is a wonderful game that is pretty much the exact same as the originals but with better handling and graphics. Would recommend, even if you don't have the nostalgia associated with it like I do.

However, this PC port is incredibly buggy ): For the first two games, it was just slightly annoying but I could look over it as it didn't fully impact my playing. Once I got to Year of the Dragon though, the mini-games because increasingly difficult to the point of having to stop playing for a bit to get over the annoyance. I've 100% this on PS4 (in game Skill Checks AND achievements) and am very nearly there for this version as well. You're constantly getting stuck in place, Spyro and enemies get submerged into the ground often, the controls for the mini-games in YotD constantly glitch out if you're using a control so you have to swap between keyboard/mouse AND controller. I've had gems get stuck in places where they are unreachable, enemies have despawned keeping me from getting all the gems to finish a level, forcing me to reload and replay a level. None of these issues were present in the Playstation version.

Play this game, absolutely, but maybe not on PC unless you're willing to deal with some really frustrating glitches and bugs
