Esto lo disfrute mucho y solo tengo que agradecer por esta obra de arte. Lo recomiendo al 100%. Muchas gracias!

128316316.review:
When it comes to the Spyro series, the first three games are undeniable classics, as not only were they made by the same team, but they also had a unified vision that made the trio seem like a true trilogy. This remaster does a great job in making that vision shine through, even if the original developers are not on board.

The graphics and music are top notch, bringing the original art style in a modern fashion that isn't too overboard but not too bland either. It's what the developers would have loved to do back on the PS1. I will say the voices are a mixed bag, as in some cases, they do just fine. I was expecting Tom Kenny to come back, as he did most of the trilogy and his voice was easy to modernize rather than Spyro 1's voice actor, a style that would have seemed out of place for this remaster. Some of the other voices are odd, such as some of the characters in the first level of Spyro 3. They just... don't seem right. A minor nitpick, but it doesn't affect the game overall.

As for the game itself, the level design and gameplay mechanics hold up very well. If you've played the originals, you'll have no problem knowing where every gem or egg is at. However, there are more glitches in this version than the originals. You really start to see the glitches when you get to the third game, as the mini-games such as the skateboarding races are a toss-up on whether you'll fail or not.

Overall, while this does have some flaws, it's a great way to introduce a new player to the Spyro series, even if the quality of the games dipped from Year of the Dragon.

Here's to hoping Activision will greenlight another sequel like they did with Crash 4.

Spyro™ Reignited Trilogy is a remastered collection of the original Spyro the Dragon games, updated with stunning new graphics and gameplay mechanics. The collection includes Spyro the Dragon, Spyro 2: Ripto's Rage!, and Spyro: Year of the Dragon, and it's a must-play for fans of the series.

The gameplay in Spyro™ Reignited Trilogy is classic Spyro the Dragon, with fast-paced platforming and exciting dragon-breathing action. The game's levels are beautifully remastered, with vibrant and detailed graphics that bring the game's colorful world to life. The game also includes new gameplay mechanics and challenges, adding to the game's replayability.

One of the standout features of Spyro™ Reignited Trilogy is its cast of lovable and memorable characters. The game includes fan-favorite characters like Spyro the Dragon, Sparx the Dragonfly, and Hunter the Cheetah, as well as a host of new and interesting characters. The game's story is charming and entertaining, and it's sure to keep players engaged.

Overall, Spyro™ Reignited Trilogy is a must-play for fans of the original Spyro the Dragon games. The collection's stunning graphics and updated gameplay mechanics make it a joy to play, and the game's memorable characters and story will keep players coming back for more. If you're a fan of the Spyro series, this is definitely a game that you should check out.

127138814.review:
Fantastic collectathon in which you play Spyro from the three original games but with all-new visuals thanks to the guys at Toys For Bob. As for the gameplay, it's relatively simple: third person, you can sprint, bash things, and breathe fire. Puzzles await that ask you to utilize these abilities, and some of these puzzles can be tricky. Each game is comprised of worlds, each world with about four or five levels (one of which is always a flying challenge), and you're basically just running around collecting gems to open up the next world.

This isn't Crash Bandicoot levels of difficult, though. In fact, it's largely not that difficult at all, and serves as the perfect game to sit back, relax, and play without much worry. For the completionists, the Reignited Trilogy is a wondrous package that's sure to keep you busy for a while.

125896143.review:
By the time the first Playstation was released I was a young adult so I don't have any nostalgia for this series.   And I think that's why I'm a bit lukewarm with Spyro Reignited Trilogy.   I think one really needs to have played this in their formative gaming years to fully appreciate SRT. 

The Good:
Graphics -- this game is a treat to behold. Simply gorgeous!

The Not-So-Good:
The music -- again, maybe I need to have played this game as a tween or something because the music doesn't seem to "fit" this game.  Was this music originally created for something else?  
The level design -- Sure the game is beautiful but the general layout of the environments seem like they were AI-generated and/or randomized like a rogue-like.

The Bad:
I don't think a lot of early 3D platformers have aged particularly well - looking at you, Super Mario 64.  We've come a long way since the mid 90's and a lot of the frustrating aspects of early 3D platformers are here such as camera issues, mindless collect-a-thon gameplay, repetition, and sometimes frustrating level design. 

Still, I'm having some fun and I think those who grew up with Spyro will have even more of a good time with this game. 

Tl; dr
Nostalgic for your Playstation 1 childhood? Buy it!
Are you just a fan of 3D platformers...and you're willing to put with old-school 3D platforming jank?  Buy it! On sale!

buy it on a very deep sale, spyro is great but this port isnt. Its literally just a console port with no effort put in.
There are loads of bugs and you cant actually progress the game unless you cap your FPS to 30, because this game was made for consoles which can only reach 30 fps. Doors simply will not open unless you cap it to 30. If you set your framerate cap to 144, you will slide around and you cant actually reach the max jump height, making some parts impossible. Capping to 120 fps fixes the sliding. 
The game also crashes frequently for some people, which I did not have thankfully. The game also has no true fullscreen, so when you rescue a dragon or any dialogue is on screen, your mouse will end up on your other monitor and  you might not be able to move because you clicked for fire breath, but in actuality you clicked your other monitor because the game doesnt have exclusive fullscreen. 
Of course, none of these bugs have been fixed and there hasnt been a single patch since this came out in 2019, because money is more important than a polished product, since toys for bob released this game and then activision forced them to work on call of duty, a VERY hard to make and highly complex game. They needed the studio's CTRL+C CTRL+V skills for another copy paste yearly call of duty I guess.

125029391.review:
Does it have its problems? Most certainly. Minor graphical bugs, a giant yeti getting pushed around by moles and gnomes, Shiela's redesign, some of the new voice acting doesn't work nearly as well as the original voices (some. Others, like Hunter, are leaps and bounds ahead of the original) and none of the artbooks are work of Elora. On the other hand, it's still incredibly charming, fun when you're not pulling your hair out over race records, nostalgic and a way to get the young'uns to play this ancient classic without a 30 year old relic.

I think they actually did rather well and hope that they continue the franchise in a way that's respectful to the original games. It's been 20 years and while the remakes ARE great, especially on the graphics and animation front, we're long overdue for another one.

124991777.review:
This game is a wonderful recreation of the original Playstation Spyro adventures. Every detail is a joy to see, the visuals are a testament to what can be done when people who truly love and care about a storied franchise are allowed to demonstrate their creativity and dedication to preserving the passion and spirit of the originals. The sound design, musical score and voice acting is all top notch and a faithful remastering of the original sound, music and dialog. The controls are just about perfect given the team at Toys for Bob had to work with control schemes two decades old and yet still work and work well. Only on occassion such as being underwater does the camera give me any issues. But even that one somewhat glaring problem does little to detract from the overall experience of an otherwise near flawless reimagining of one of the most beloved franchise trilogies of all time. This is Spyro done right and most important of all, this is Insomniac Studios being paid proper tribute in spite of the fact their studio name isn't featured. Toys for Bob are the kind of people that I can trust to handle remakes of these and other classic games of yore.

Thank you Toys for Bob. Thank you for doing Spyro right!

124341522.review:
TL;DR: The Spyro Reignited Trilogy is a great collection for its price if you enjoy sandbox-style 3D platformers. It has its fair share of faults, but is still full of charm and fun to play. Achievements Level: Easy.

I played the original Spyro as a kid, so going back into this game and 100%ing it was a bit of a no-brainer for me. I think for the price it is it's absolutely worth getting, especially on sale. However, that doesn't mean it's not without its fair share of issues.

The game is plagued with lots of problems revolving around poor optimization for PCs. Higher framerates can hurt the gameplay or straight up softlock you from beating certain bosses. Cutscenes are choppy at times and the collision for ledges and enemies are pretty awkward. Spyro 3 has a skateboard race section and it's awful I hate it. Certain quality of life mechanics are added/taken away from game to game (Gem colors change between 1 and 2, 2 has a theater for rewatching cutscenes that isn't present for 1 or 3, 2's levels reset after leaving whereas 3s doesnt, etc), which is very odd to me given how much of the rest of it had been standardized. A lot of 3s side characters are very sluggish to control, especially on a controller.

As for the good, these games are absolutely gorgeous and full of life. Characters (especially in the first game) are very well animated and most of the humor is still great even if it's pretty childish. The gameplay for Spyro himself is very solid and thrives in its simplicity.

Spyro 1 is short and sweet, I think it's still the best game in the package for me. It just has some great and memorable worlds, areas, and characters. Story is simple (which is the standard for all three games honestly) and the boss fights are laughably easy. Lots of secrets and challenges to find that the sequels just don't do as well imo. 

Spyro 2 has some pretty memorable hub worlds and levels, but replaying them can be a pain since they reset once you leave. The story is the most expansive in this trilogy, lots of cute cutscenes for each individual area and new characters with a lot more relevancy/presence than 3s. The boss fights, power ups, and 100% reward are very well done, easily the best of the trilogy. 

Spyro 3 was my least favorite, it was fun to play for the most part but largely forgettable. The new playable characters feel really bad to play with the exception of Spark and Agent 9 (on mouse and keyboard, at least), and they don't really serve a purpose to the game at large other than some diversity in gameplay. Each level loops around in some fashion, making it very easy to revisit each one and find missing special stages, gems, or eggs. Boss fights feel awkward and boring. The 100% reward is both very satisfying and very underwhelming, especially in comparison to 2s.

As for achievements, the game is very easy to 100%. Skill Point challenges don't have any related achievements, and neither does 100%ing Spyro 3 for some odd reason. Most achievements can be earned playing organically, with some special challenges like burning specific objects in certain levels. I very much enjoyed the hunt in this game.

124283578.review:
*played on both steam deck & switch (completed on switch)

Things I liked:
[list]
    [*] Value for money (all 3 games + bonus content in 1 package)
    [*] Tons of level variety in both gameplay mechanics and theme
    [*] Lots of fun and interesting challenges (probably at least 50% of the main challenges actually are separate little gameplay tracks and not just gotten along the way or by doing something super quick & simple)
[/list]

Things I didn't like:
[list]
    [*] Some of the game modes/minigames just aren't fun
    [*] Not a big fan of the gem system (it's kind of a currency for unlocks but not really and since they are collectibles and not currency they have to be found in very specific spots. At times this is aggravating because there is one gem on top of an obscure rooftop or something and you waste 30 minutes trying to find it).
    [*] Many of the "challenges" are not really challenging or interesting (like sometimes all you do is glide easily to a platform that is out in the open)
    [*] Performance on switch is sub-par. Does not maintain 30 FPS during heavy action on levels where enemies kind of swarm. This doesn't happen often but I would guess that it was dropping all the way to ~20 FPS which is not only noticeable but actually disruptive to gameplay and it made the game miss some of my inputs. I didn't make it far enough on steam deck to get a sense for this.
[/list]

124270034.review: I grew up with the wrong Spyro games for this to feel satisfying. If Spyro: adventure/Spyro: Attack of the Rhynocs, and/or Spyro: a new beginning were the games you grew up with, this game is going to feel really shallow, being mostly driven by a "collect all the shiny things" vibe. I miss the puzzle-like exploration and trying to figure out how to get to the next location from Spyro: adventure, and I miss the story and characters from Spyro: a new beginning. This game feels incredibly hand-holdy, telling you exactly what you need to do and how to get to certain places. Granted, I only played for briefly over an hour, but I would expect the "tutorial level" to max out 15 minutes, and I just got so bored I couldn't keep going...

Good remake of a good trilogy, but I can't recommend this broken PC port.

The game supports high frame rates, and allows you to set your FPS cap to whatever you want in the menu. The problem is that for a lot of stages, anything above 30 will break the game. Jumps can be harder, catching the egg thieves is made more difficult and some mechanics simply won't work when you're above 30. If you dare set your FPS into the hundreds you will have Spyro sliding around the map like he's on ice.

So if you ever find yourself struggling with a stage you first have to work out if it's the frame rate that's stopping you from progressing or if you are genuinely missing something. It spoils the sense of challenge and progression.

123706581.review:
I may not have played the original Spyro games on PS1 back in the day, but I thought this trilogy was an absolutely fantastic collection of games! 

The world is bright and colourful and cheery, and it's fun to romp around as a purple dragon and stick your snout into every corner of it, gliding hither and yon on your wings, ramming bad guys with your horns, and setting all manner of things on fire with your species' signature flame breath. 

The controls are mostly smooth and tight, and the exceptions to that rule are all side events and minigames, not central gameplay, Spyro himself is a treat to control. I'm told that some of the control schemes (namely, the skateboarding stuff in "Spyro: Year of the Dragon") have gotten significantly worse than in the original games, but on the other hand, I've also heard that a couple of the bosses are waaaaaaaaaaay less difficult than their original, infamously OP versions, so it's a bit of a mixed bag. 

They've replaced the primitive 3D graphics of the PlayStation 1 with unexpectedly beautiful graphics rendered in Unreal 4, which feels kinda like overkill, but undeniably makes the game absolutely gorgeous. 

The stories may be shallow, especially "Spyro the Dragon", but the characters themselves are deeply endearing, and I loved taking part in their adventures. 

I won't lie, there are some VERY frustrating bits in this game, especially if you get bitten by the Completionist Bug like I did (I would certainly call 337% "complete" anyway), but patience, determination, and a little bit of luck and stubbornness will see you through. 

All in all, this is a lovely update to some widely-beloved classics, and I'm tickled pink that I finally got to experience these games I missed in my childhood. If you like platformers, especially oldschool collect-a-thons with lots of minigames, I absolutely recommend the Spyro Reignited Trilogy... and hope that Toys for Bob cooks up some new Spyro content soon! :-)

122761353.review:
[b]Don't let the idea of Activision publishing this game put you off![/b] Toys for Bob did justice for the trilogy of Spyro the Dragon. I am a little bias as 9 year old me played these games over and over on the trusty PlayStation 1. Overall my expectations was high and exceeded above and beyond when playing these for the 94758375th time, but rebuilt and remade!

Remembering how satisfying it was to collect every single gem was well, satisfying! The completion-ist in me started with this very game back in the day. The sounds, the music, the voice cast, how well they customised every single dragon and characters in the games is [b]S Tier.[/b] They all have their own personalities, but amplified by [b]10,000![/b]

And the coolest part is; you can play this game as Spyro, but with [b]sunglasses.[/b] They re-added old codes and added some new ones you can put into game whenever you want and it will never effect your achievements! Awesome right?! Not that I would need the 99 skill points, I'm sure some first timers would benefit from it greatly ;)

Just some small issues here and there, like how some gems wont get picked up unless you physically put Spyro on them, but this is a 0.01% occurrence, not every gem is like this. Some of the hit boxes in the environment are questionable, and sometimes gliding/platforming isn't the same as it was on the crisp PlayStation 1, but this is to be expected. They made the game easy, but not too easy, overall this game is just bloody great.

My advice for new people who use controller; don't use the trigger for flaming enemies, you'll find it's much quicker with the action button! And as for moving the camera, you'll find you won't need to use it that often, using the R3 Analog stick for flight levels just make things harder for yourself and you're better off just hitting the action button the centres the camera for you instead!

[/list]

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
The [i] Spyro Reignited Trilogy[/i] is a fantastic blast from the past that fans of the series will find immense value in. Though a lot of its gameplay, level, and enemy design will feel dated, it's a simple game that's accessible for all audiences. If you're an adult who can find enjoyment in a Dreamworks film, you'll find little issue with this package.
[b] Should you buy it? [/b]: If you catch this on sale, it's worth picking up if you have even a mild interest in the series and the platformer genre.

[h1] 4/5 [/h1]

Most HD reworks of old games lose a lot of their soul, and while Spyro lost some too (for example, the multi-scene level transitions), it clearly tries its hardest to retain as much as possible (for example, you can now fiddle around with different movements during level transition). 122156509.review:
3 of the best collect-a-thon games ever to have been created. Spyro the Dragon is a game about freeing the Dragon Kingdom from the evil forces. The content is split between standard levels - where the objective is to collect all the gems (by defeating enemies, exploring and solving puzzles), free the imprisoned dragons and catch the thieves that have stolen the dragon eggs; flight levels - where the level is played as a free-flight dragon and the goal is to complete the 4 objectives as fast as possible; and boss levels - where you fight the boss in an arena. The later games also add mini-games on top of this, as well as other characters.

The PC port is a little rough around the edges, particularly if you play it on a controller. Steam fortunately has good controller remapping support, allowing you to for example increase the joystick sensitivity, which is not possible in game.

There is also something to be said about the remaster losing some of the charm the original had. I agree this is the case, but given the difficulty of playing the original games in a HD format I would say it is worth the trade off.

Overall I would recommend the game(s). They're a fun, polished collect-a-thon experience, and probably the best trilogy of collect-a-thon games ever created.

122128328.review:
I never got to play the originals as a kid. Despite that, these were an incredibly fun experience, and while some facets of their design have grown over the years as game development has progressed, this return to form was incredibly touching even to someone who hadn't had the nostalgia. A gold standard in remastering, from the absolutely incredible art direction to the wonderful sound design. While the controls will take a bit to get used to, to those who are more used to more modern games, they come very naturally, very quickly.

A few bugs here in the PC port, including a couple visual hiccups in animation (Spyro floating outside a balloon, mouth movements sometimes not playing) to ice-level-like physics everywhere when FPS is set at 144 or unlimited (Setting to 120 or lower fixed this for me without sacrificing much). Nothing gamebreaking, so far as I came across, though, so really only minor complaints. Weirdest bug or oversight is that the game will try to also launch SteamVR -- simply right-click your game, go to Properties, and in the launch options, enter "-nohmd" without quotations to fix this!

Loved my time here. Once I started, it was just such a treat to the eyes and ears that I binged them all back-to-back. To those who played them in the past, you'll find such love here that you shouldn't pass it up, and the huge leap in visual fidelity is worth your return to the dragon worlds. To those who also have kids now, this trilogy will absolutely delight them, too. I'm left desperately wishing for more. I truly hope we see more Spyro in this form again in the future, because I've become a fan, 20+ years later. Thanks, Toys for Bob.

122124457.review:
Spyro Reignited seems like an incredibly faithful update to the original PS1 games. Unfortunately, I think that comes at the cost of some inherit clunkiness that keeps this collection from being a must-play platformer. Although the level designs are gorgeous and have fun layouts to explore, they seem to call for a level of precision that your character doesn't posses. 

Spyro has a painfully wide turning radius that leads to constantly missing enemies during charges and falling off platforms when you simply meant to turn around. Exacerbating these sluggish controls are a jumps and glides that have incredibly tight tolerances. Whether I was going to make it to the next platform by a few centimetres or headbutt the side of it always felt like a guessing game. If Spyro was a more responsive character, I would chalk it up to "git gud", but when he has all the agility of a semi-truck, it's hard not to feel frustrated. 

Aside from beautiful character and level design, there's just not much going on in Spyro Reignited. The story is threadbare, and combat boils down to headbutt/firebreath before the enemy can trade hits with you. That means the platforming has to carry a lot of weight here, and I simply don't think the controls are up to the task. I think die-hard fans of the original games will find a lot to love, but I'm willing to leave this one in the past.

121910761.review: Reignited is a great name for this game! It really reignited my memories of playing Spyro on my PS1 a while ago. The games are the same, except that the sound effects and soundtrack are improved and the graphics are brand new. The most impressive graphic-related aspect, in my opinion, are the dragons you save in the first game. It's evident that they dedicated a lot of time to create their concepts and sometimes the dragon just say "thank you" and fly away. But talking more about the games: the 1st one is nice and the dragons are cool; the 2nd one, I think is the best, because there are some new game mechanics, the storyline is more cohesive, the main antagonist has a lot of personality and I like the level designs and soundtrack on this one better; the 3rd is my least favorite because the story on this one is too childish to my taste, with a lot of irony and some romantic interest among characters, and there are new playable characters that don't do much and are not nearly charismatic as Spyro is. In general, the three games are not hard for curious completionists, and, once again, the second one is my favorite under this aspect because it is better designed and more challenging. Anyway, it is a nice and refined trip to the past appropriate to all ages.

121705881.review:
The original 3 Spyro games are classics and should be experienced by any gamer especially Spyro 2 Ripto's Rage. I already completed the Reignited Trilogy on the Switch a couple years ago but decided to double-dip during the $14 sale going on until September 5th 2022, so who could pass up that deal? Plus, I've always wanting to own the Spyro Reignited Trilogy on my PC.

Spyro 1 is the first and has those examples of "Early Installment Weirdness" since Spyro can't hover, the Hub worlds are lethal, the bosses are HARDLY considered bosses. If I can explain it clear, the "bosses" in Spyro 1 more resemble bigger stage enemies. Nothing about them feel like bosses...the music doesn't change, there's no pre-cutscene, there's no HP meter, they're more stage obstacles that need to be defeated especially "Blowhard" since you flame him throughout the stage rather than a one-on-one battle. Toasty's design is amazing though, really love the Reignited Trilogy's redesign on him. One stage that stands out is Dark Hollow. I loved it in the original game, BUT I love it even more in this remake since they added it to become a library. This game can take 5-6 hours to finish. If you're a marathon player, maybe even faster.

Spyro 2: Ripto's Rage is the best game in my opinion out of the trilogy. It took aspects of the first game and improved upon them: giving Spyro a hover, new flight and breath abilities, swimming, headbashing, stage NPC's. The bosses are great too and all three of them are established from the very beginning as Crush, Gulp and Ripto, unlike the last game's main threat being Gnasty Gnorc and his nobody henchmen. There are stages you have to come back to when you've learned new abilities, but it evens out in a way where it is not that much of a hassle.

Then last we have Spyro 3: Year of the Dragon, which people often view as the BEST game of the original trilogy. I disagree. Spyro 2 had that perfect balance of fleshing out the world and abilities of Spyro, but Spyro 3 adds too much. New characters, new gameplay styles such as skateboarding, boxing, tanks, PLENTY of backtracking... You can't complete each hub world and its stages in order. You have to go to the next hub world, finish the new chararacter's stage, go back and get all the side egg quests that were locked behind the new character wall and if you get too ahead, you can't do any of Hunter's missions until you defeat Scorch. Sparx is also added as a playable character and has the same issue of a new gameplay style and only being able to enter his stages if you defeated a boss or gotten enough eggs. Speedway stages also add races. It's like a step forward and a step back with the new characters and poorly developed bosses...which although actual bosses, seem to have Spyro 1 issues lacking identities since we get a small cutscene of Bianca or the Sorceror turning foot pawns or butterfly fodder as the bosses, unlike Crush and Gulp who were Ripto's minions from the beginning. What's even more insulting is Spyro doesn't even get a cutscene with the final boss, the Sorceror when the Reignited Trilogy could've fixed that and given one with her which the original game lacked. 

Anyways, I completed Spyro 3 on the Switch and as of this writing, am only 84% finished. Overall, Spyro Reignited Trilogy is a great experience and is a classic collect-a-thon. Pick it up while it's on sale for a bargain price of $14 for THREE great games!

121597097.review:
I had never played the original Spyro the Dragon, so I have no nostalgia to go by. At face value, Spyro is a repetitive collectathon. You go through every level collecting things. When you haven't collected enough, you have to backtrack and collect more. Levels are very small and enemies tend to fall into the category of "use the first attack" or "use the second attack" with variety in the form of "wait until some character animation is over then attack". 
The controls and camera make running awkward and platforming clunky. Jumping puzzles are the worst. Being even a sliver of distance off of a perfect jump will make you fail and have to start over, which makes it very frustrating that you [i]must[/i] finish every jumping puzzle to complete the collectathon to continue the game. 
And that's been the entire experience of Spyro. Every level feels same-y, the enemies feel same-y, and collecting everything is a chore. Like a watered down Super Mario 64 with worse controls, platforming, and level designs.

121567815.review:
The graphics are absolutely gorgeous - the original games were obviously remastered with care and attention.

At first I thought that the games didn't feel like the originals, but I checked - they feel almost identical. Jumping, gliding, charging, killing enemies... all of it! The voices, sound effects and the soundtrack have all been updated to better fit the enhanced graphics, and I have no real complaints about these.

The games perform well; everything runs silky smooth without chugging. Only in one very limited area in Spyro 2 did I notice any drops in framerate, but even then it wasn't anything unbearable.

Highly recommended for both kids and adults. This would be a great introduction to Spyro for the young ones of today.

121554056.review: A great collect-a-thon platformer. The second and third games add minigames that break up some of the monotony of otherwise just collecting loads of gems. Some of these minigames are fun, others are annoying, and some are outright frustrating. However these minigames are optional, so they do not harm the game unless you are going for the "337%" i.e., getting everything.

EDIT BELOW: a smooth playing, good looking remake of one of my favorite game franchises. some jumps i think have different hitbox's because there a couple jumps that are rough. you don't want to know how many times i died on tree tops with the cross map supercharge.

121446003.review:
Esta trilogía me parece sencillamente magnífica, no voy a decir que no me la pille por nostalgia de jugar al 1 y a ver si por fin me lo terminaba, y no solo lo hice si no que lo exprimí al máximo y después de eso fueron el 2 y el 3.
Son juegos de plataformas 3D muy divertidos, con movimientos básicos pero que casan perfecto con el plataformeo. Jugáblemente son, por lo que he oído, idénticos a los originales salvo porque ahora podemos usar joystick para movernos y para la cámara, cosa que no tenían los primeros mandos de PS1; yo puedo confirmar que por lo menos el primer juego es idéntico a nivel jugable y ha envejecido muy bien.
El 1 me pareció el mejor, quizá sea por nostalgia pero me parece que es el que más personalidad tiene. Respecto al 2 y 3 evidentemente se centraron más en historia y NPC's cosa que no me parece mal pero que en ciertos momentos me parece que no pega con lo visto en el primer juego.
Visualmente es precioso y han hecho un lavado de cara estupendo tanto a escenarios como a personajes.

Ahora voy con lo malo:
Los tiempos de carga entre mundos son un poco largos (sobre todo en el 1) pero nada insoportable, nada comparado con lo que voy a decir a continuación al menos...
Para mi el peor ha sido el 3, y no porque sea un mal juego si no porque no podía evitar tener la sensación constante de que la hitbox no estaba tan bien pulida como en los otros dos, lo cual me extraña muchísimo porque a nivel técnico es a efectos prácticos el mismo juego dividido en 3 partes. Pero lo dicho, llamaradas que según el primer y segundo juego deberían dar pero no llegaban por poco en el tercero y también pasar por el borde del aro correspondiente en las pruebas de vuelo y que a veces cuente y a veces no, como digo, solo en el tercero. 
Y bueno, lo peor para mi sin duda son los minijuegos de monopatín del tercer juego, quizá sea solo cosa mía pero os juro que no se a quien le pareció una buena idea poner a un dragoncito haciendo skate. En estos minijuegos es donde he notado más las hitbox rarunas y ademas para los aterrizajes te pide ser super preciso. Si no vas a conseguir todos los coleccionables pues te dará más igual, pero si quieres conseguirlo todo en el juego pues esto puede ser un autentico dolor de cabeza, por lo menos para mi lo fue.

Respecto a bugs la verdad es que son casi inexistentes y digo casi porque hay uno que te vas a encontrar creo que obligatoriamente: En el primer juego, en el mundo ''Cresta Alpina'' llegará un momento en que no podrás seguir el camino si juegas a 60 FPS, la solución es bajarlo a 30, cosa que puedes hacer en cualquier momento. No es un gran dolor de cabeza sabiendo la solución pero me parece feo que no lo arreglen.

Dicho todo esto, salvando las extrañas hitbox del 3 y los minijuegos de skate del mismo y ese único bug importante estos juegos me parecen extremadamente disfrutables tanto si quieres rejugar los clásicos como si los quieres jugar por primera vez.

121445179.review:
Coming up to a 100% playthrough of the first game at 12 hours of gameplay, im at 85% currently. 
I have not played the other 2 games in the trilogy yet.

This was one of the very first games i ever played as a child so i am going to be biased.

ACTUAL REVIEW:
For a quick answer, this game is amazing and whether or not you have played this in the past, its a great game to pick up if you enjoy cartoony platformers.

Everything in this game feels nostalgic to the original with the biggest changes to the game being, graphics, controls, and the art style of the dragons. Graphics are amazing, no high end system required. The controls feel completely different to the original ( Although you can choose the classic controls in the settings ). While the new control scheme feels so much better, it makes the gliding, parkour and enemies a TON easier to get around which might make the game too easy for some. There are still very tough levels with either controls though. The new dragons art style are overall great with some being a bit weird but there are SO many to find that it doesn't even concern you eventually. I havn't had encountered a single bug and i have explored every nook and cranny of world 1 - 5 on spyro 1.

This game is making me also want to buy the remastered Crash Bandicoot. Perfect Remaster.

121379868.review:
GREAT FOR CHILDREN, LITTLE APPEAL TO ADULTS

I loved this game when I was a child. Spyro and Crash Bandicoot were two of my favorites on PS1. I was excited to play the remake, for I loved what they did with Crash Bandicoot.

But I had a refund after trying 2 of the 3 entries on this trilogy. The game is simplistic to a fault. I knew it was meant for children, but many such games also appeal to adults. Spyro is not one of those.

I imagine some people still love the simple gameplay. Some love the nostalgia. Some will enjoy this game with their children. I am none of the above. If you expect this game to be like Crash Bandicoot you will be disappointed.

That said, the game is beautiful, and ran smoothly on my rig (Ryzen 3100, 16GB RAM, RX 580 4GB). That is why I cannot give this remake a thumbs down.
